item.title: The Small Business Guide To Good Book Keeping
item.dc:creator: Black And White Accounting
item.content:encoded:
We know, a love of book keeping isn’t what you went into business for! As accountants and book keepers perhaps we take an unhealthy interest in the subject! But for us, every successful business keeps accurate and up-to-date financial records. Good book keeping is the foundation of any financial structure and without it, any decision based on out-of-date or incomplete financial information from your business is built on a foundation of sand. Keeping regular accounts will become even more important when HMRC eventually rolls out Making Tax Digital. (Its plan to make us file online tax returns every quarter!)

Top five book keeping tips for keeping on top of your accounts

At Black and White Accounting, we have a team of experienced and veteran(!) bookkeepers, their top five tips for keeping on top of your accounts are…
  1. Be consistent.
  2. File all documentation in date order. Never back date entries on your accounting systems.
  3. Number sales invoices and bank statements sequentially. Keep all entries completely transparent.
  4. Keep business and personal accounts separate. Identify any personal entries.
  5. Put as much detail as you can into description boxes.
Please don’t be embarrassed to ask your accountant / bookkeeper for help or advice! They should always be there to support you.

Download your free guide to book keeping

We like to make life easier for our clients! Our team has designed a step by step guide for all matters related to bookkeeping, this will help you to better understand how to organise your own company’s financial records. If you want to take the stress out of book keeping and stay on top of your routine accounts, download our FREE guide [LANDING PAGE] here. Online accounting If you aren’t already, have you considered using cloud based software? Not only does it make your book keeping and accounts easier to keep up to date, but you’ll have access to a range of current information to help you make key business decisions. If you’d like to investigate cloud accounting for your business, Black and White Accounting offer training and support for Xero, QuickBooks Online and Sage One. You can find out more here. How Black and White Accounting can help We are always happy to answer enquiries from clients about book keeping! In fact if the truth be told, we’d rather deal with problems as they occur than at the end of the accounting period! Ask us how we can help you and your business on freephone number 0800 140 4644 or freephone mobile 0333 370 6566.

item.title: Electric cars from April 2020
item.dc:creator: Black And White Accounting
item.content:encoded:
The company car has been a favourite target for the Government and the taxman for a decade or more now so much so that it’s actually hard to decide whether it’s a perk of the job or not anymore. However, in the global effort to push green technologies onto an ever more willing public increasingly concerned about the future of the environment, the company car may have had a reprieve. A partial reprieve we’re quick to add because it only applies to the cleanest and greenest cars. The rate on no-emission and low-emission cars dropped dramatically on the 5th April 2020 although, given what’s been happening in the world in recent months, it’s not surprising that this change will have passed many people by. In this article, we explain in detail (using as little jargon as possible) this important change includes:
  • what company car tax is
  • what P11d is and what it means in relation to the value of a car
  • how to work out company car tax
  • a worked example to demonstrate the big difference in cost by going electric
  • the advantages and disadvantages of going electric
  • getting advice from an accountant on electric cars and company cars in general

What is company car tax?

You may have heard of benefits-in-kind (BiK) – they are non-monetary incentives and rewards given by a company to an employee. Standard benefits-in-kind include childcare, health insurance, and company cars. Each year, nearly all of the benefits-in-kind given to an employee must be shared with HMRC via a P11d form. The employee then pays income tax and National Insurance on the value of the benefits and the company pays National Insurance Employers’ Contributions. Except in the rarest of cases, HMRC does not accept appeals to waive benefits-in-kind payments on a company car on the grounds that the car is only used for business purposes. They will contend that the employee derives personal benefit from the use of the car – this includes the commute into work.

The P11d value of car

Cars are expensive and it would be unreasonable to ask a basic rate taxpayer, for example, to pay tax of 20% on the entire value of a company car at its new retail price all in one go. Instead, HMRC calculates the benefit-in-kind value of the car based upon a calculation which includes:
  • the price of the car minus registration fee, road tax, and other non-taxable costs (the manufacturer sets the value of the car) and
  • the amount of pollution it produces as measured by grams per kilometre of CO2

How to work out company car tax

To work out company car tax, you first find the P11d value of your car. You then multiply that P11d value by the company car tax rate – those rates are in the table below:

Finally, that value is multiplied by the income tax rate the employee pays. In England, Wales, and Northern Ireland, that’s 20% for people earning up to £50,000, 40% for people earning between £50,001 and £150,000, and 45% for people earning £150,001 and above.

Worked example

As you can see from the table above, the P11d value of cars with zero emissions and those with emissions of between 1 and 50 grams drops dramatically from the 2019/2020 tax year to the 2020/2021 tax year. A drop this substantial is likely to shape the choices made by companies when ordering the fleet for their staff. Not only do the staff benefit but so does the company in the form of lower National Insurance Employers’ Contribution payments. How would this work in the real world? Let’s compare how much cheaper the choice of a zero-emission car is with a standard car powered by an internal combustion engine. Let’s consider a BMW 520d M Sport 4dr Auto with 151g/km of emissions and the zero emission Tesla Model 3 Long Range AWD 4dr Auto.

The BMW would cost your employee £17,049 over the 3 years in comparison to £588 for the Tesla. That is quite an incentive. Will it fast forward the adoption of zero and low emission driving in the UK? We’ll know in a couple of years’ time.

Advantages and disadvantages of going electric

The financial advantage to switching to electric cars is clear from the worked example above. In addition, businesses purchasing ultra-low or no emission vehicles qualify for a 100% first year allowance – that’s equivalent to full tax relief on the car in the year it was purchased. Electric cars are expensive to purchase however prices have begun to fall in recent years. Some employees may also be reluctant to make the switch because of fears over the lack of charging points (especially if they don’t have a charging point installed at their premises), the time cars take to charge, the range of the batteries, and, according to many, they’re not particularly enjoyable to drive.

Company cars and your business

item.title: In debt to HMRC?
item.dc:creator: Black And White Accounting
item.content:encoded:
Owing someone or another company money is always stressful but, when you’re in debt to HM Revenue and Customs, it can be a particularly uncomfortable experience. If you have fallen into arrears on your tax payments, you can guarantee that HMRC will do everything in their power to make sure they get the money they’re owed. If you find yourself in this situation, what do you need to know. In this article, we’ll cover:
  • the powers the tax man actually has
  • the value in talking to HMRC
  • the Time to Pay system
  • whether a loan is the right course of action
  • the benefits of speaking with an accountant about HMRC debt

HMRC’s infinite power with revenue debt

The taxman is the most serious creditor you can have chasing you for payment because HMRC has a whole range of powers available to it for collecting the money you owe them. Back in April 2014, a new law was passed allowing HMRC to seize tax that is owed directly from an individual’s or a company’s bank account. While they will issue a number of warnings before they do this, HMRC may even choose to have your bank account frozen as a warning sign to you that they will be taking the money soon. They are, however, bound by the rule that they must leave at least £5,000 across your bank and savings accounts and that they can only seize amounts upwards of £1,000. A spokesperson for HMRC told the Telegraph that HMRC can “take money from any account – including any type of Isa – it does not matter where they are held,” but that “the people we are targeting will have had plenty of warning and time to settle their affairs.” In addition to this direct recovery of debt, HMRC have other ‘enforcement actions’ in their repertoire to recover the money they are owed. These include:

Court action

If you do not pay the money you owe HMRC, they may decide to take you to court. Should the court uphold HMRC’s decision, you could be made to pay court fees and HMRC’s costs on top of the tax you owe. Read more about court action here.

Distraint

This involves HMRC taking the assets that you own from you and then selling them to pay off your debt. They send a bailiff or enforcement officer to your home or business to seize property that will cover the cost of your tax bill plus certain fees. Find out more on the gov.uk website.

Bankruptcy

If you do not pay your tax bill or your debts to HMRC exceed the assets you own, you could be made bankrupt. When this happens you may lose your home, business, savings, and investments in the process. See more about what happens during bankruptcy here.

HMRC Security Bonds

When HMRC suspect there is a risk you will not pay your future tax liabilities on time, they can ask you to pay a deposit – or bond – on various types of tax. If your business is issued a Notice of Requirement for security then the debt can even be transferred to you personally. Read more here.

Winding up petition

Failing to pay your company’s tax bills (corporation tax, VAT, and PAYE) could result in a winding up petition being issued. If you don’t pay back the amount HMRC are demanding within seven days, your bank accounts will be frozen, you will not be able to sell or transfer any company assets, and other creditors could use the same petition to wind up your company. See what happens following a winding up order here. How should you handle HMRC if you owe them money that you can’t pay back within the timeframe given by HMRC?

Talk to HMRC

If you know you can’t pay your bill when it arrives, the first course of action should always be to get in touch with HMRC directly. Simply not paying your tax may appear to them like evasion which is a serious criminal offence. HMRC may agree that you won’t be able to pay the total bill upfront and they will often offer a solution to help you meet your tax obligations without financially crippling you.

Time to Pay Arrangements

Payment plans like a time-to-pay arrangement give you the option to pay the tax you owe in more manageable monthly instalments rather than in one big lump sum. It is important to note that time to pay arrangements only apply to the tax arrears in question. You will still be required to pay all future taxes on time and in full. If you are struggling with your tax bill, contact HMRC ahead of your payment deadline to ask if this would be available to you. You can find out more about Time To Pay here and you can apply to pay tax in instalments here.

Use a loan

Since HMRC have begun escalating the number of winding up orders they’re issuing, some businessowners choose to take out loans to pay all of their overdue tax bill in one go. You can then spread the cost of your tax bill across a year or a number of years with your monthly loan repayments. Please note that the interest on any loan you take out will mean that you end up paying your finance provider more than you would have paid HMRC. One of the most common type of loans taken out to service an HMRC debt is a bridging loan – please be careful with these as they require security. If you only have equity in your primary residential property, the bridging loan company will accept that but, because it’s secured on your own home, it’s regulated and you’ll have a maximum of 12 months before you have to pay the loan back in full.

Work with your accountant

If you are in VAT arrears or if you are having trouble meeting your PAYE bill, you should try to negotiate with HMRC wherever possible. This is a good time to take advantage of your accountant’s experience in dealing with the taxman. They will, in many cases, be able to help you to reach an agreement with HMRC to help you manage and pay down the debt.

Work with Black and White Accounting

If we foresee that you may have trouble paying HMRC when a bill becomes due, we’ll let you know that we have concerns. Working with your accountant will give you the time you need to make cutbacks in your spending, to push customers to pay their invoices, and to make alternative arrangements with HMRC for a payment plan. At Black and White Accounting we have over 150 years’ experience between us in helping private and corporate clients minimise the amount of tax they pay as well as negotiating with HMRC on how arrears can be managed and paid back. Call our team today on freephone 0800 140 4644 or email us at hello@blackandwhiteaccounting.co.uk.

item.title: Marriage allowance
item.dc:creator: Black And White Accounting
item.content:encoded:
Despite it feeling to the contrary sometimes, not every penny we earn is taken by HMRC. There are number of different tax allowances that we can take advantage of which shields some of our income from the public purse. The most significant of these is the Personal Allowance – currently set at £12,500, whatever we earn under that amount attracts no income tax. Of course, it’s not quite true that we don’t pay any tax on earnings below that amount. We start paying National Insurance at 12% once our earnings reach £9,516 a year. For the self-employed, it’s worse – you pay Class 2 NI when your profits/income reaches £6,475 a year. One of the newer tax-saving incentives is the marriage allowance – a tax-free amount of money which means that, under certain circumstances, you’ll be taxed up to £250 less if you are one of a married couple or a civil partnership. In this article, we’ll cover:
  • what the marriage allowance is
  • who qualifies to receive it
  • what the current financial thresholds are for a successful application
  • how you apply for it
  • what happens if your spouse or civil partner has died recently
  • how you receive the money
  • how to claim for previous years if you have not yet done so

What is the Marriage Allowance?

The UK Marriage Allowance is a benefit available to married couples or those in a civil partnership. The higher-earning spouse may receive up to an additional £1,250 on top of their personal allowance in the form of a transfer from their lower earning partner. To qualify, the higher earner must pay income tax at the basic rate and the lower earning must not earn more than the personal allowance. The Marriage Allowance allows the lower earning partner to gift 10% of their personal allowance to their higher earning partner up to a value of £1,250. In effect, this would mean that the higher earning partner’s personal allowance is now £13,750 and not £12,500. As they are not paying tax on this additional £1,250, they save £250 – the basic rate of tax is 20%. Currently, for the lower earning partner to transfer £1,250 to their higher earning partner, they must earn less than £11,250. What about when a lower earning partner earns £11,500, for example? The higher earning partner would still receive the £1,250 addition to their personal allowance, but you would pay tax on £250. Likewise, if the lower earning partner earned £12,000, they would pay 20% tax on £750 and their partner would still get the additional £1,250 on their personal income.

Who qualifies to receive Marriage Allowance?

The following criteria need to be met in order for you and your partner to benefit from the Marriage Allowance:
  • be married or in a civil partnership
  • both must be born after April 5th, 1935 – if one, or both of you was born before this, you should apply to claim the ‘Married Couple’s Allowance’ which is a slightly different system
  • one member of the couple must earn below the basic allowance while the other partner earns above it and currently pays income tax at the basic rate.

What is the current financial threshold for marriage allowance?

In England, the lower earning partner must earn no more than £12,500 per year. The higher earner in the marriage must earn between £12,500 and £50,000. In Scotland, there is a slight difference. The higher earner must be earning between £12,500 and £43,430 – however the rate is at 20%.

How do I apply for marriage allowance and will my tax code change?

The Marriage Allowance scheme is organised through HMRC. Individuals should apply either through via the HMRC website or by calling them on 0200 300 3300. If you qualify, the recipient’s tax code will usually change to ‘M’ to state that they are receiving a marriage allowance from their partner. The partner who transfers the money will usually have their tax code changed to ‘N’, showing that they too are using the marriage allowance taxing system.

What happens if my partner died recently? Can I apply and get it backdated?

Yes. If your spouse died after April 5th, 2016, you are eligible to apply for Marriage Allowance including backdated claims (more on those later). In this case, you should ring HMRC Income Tax Helpline and discuss this with them.

How will we receive the money for our marriage allowance?

The partner whose personal allowance has been increased pays a lower amount of tax on their salary every month.

Will we pay tax on the money we ‘earn’ through this?

No. The marriage allowance is an incentive and you do not get taxed on this money. It’s a way of paying less tax when one partner is not using all of their personal allowance.

Backdating claims

The Marriage Allowance was first introduced in the 2015/2016 tax year. In 2017, up to two million UK couples were not claiming for this allowance when they were entitled to it. You can claim Marriage Allowance retrospectively for up to four years.
  • 2018/19 tax year: up to £1,190 of the lower earner's personal allowance may be transferred with a maximum £238 tax saving per household.
  • 2017/18 tax year: up to £1,150 of the lower earner's personal allowance may be transferred with a maximum £230 tax saving per household.
  • 2016/17 tax year: up to £1,100 of the lower earner's personal allowance may be transferred with a maximum £220 tax saving per household.
You may apply for a retrospective payment online at HMRC’s website – click here. Your refund is paid by cheque. Help with tax allowances from Black and White Accounting The marriage allowance tax is one of the many different methods you can use to save a small amount of money you pay in tax each year. Depending on your personal circumstances, there may be other incentives you qualify for. Here at Black and White Accounting, we help clients save as much money on how much tax they pay every year. We offer new clients a free one-hour consultation to find out if you are making best use of the tax breaks available to you and your family. To get in touch with us, please call on freephone 0800 140 4644, or email us at hello@blackandwhiteaccounting.co.uk.

item.title: Minimum wage versus living wage
item.dc:creator: Black And White Accounting
item.content:encoded:
Income disparity has been a growing concern for some time among politicians and campaigners. For many people who work hourly paid jobs, it can be incredibly difficult to make ends meet. In the ten years following the Great Recession of 2008, inflation outstripped wage growth in many of those years. The UK introduced The Minimum Wage on the 1st of April 1999. The new law meant that employers were now legally obliged to pay their staff a set amount of money (or more) per hour for the labour they provided. We’ve had over 20 years of the Minimum Wage in the UK yet and, in that time, it has risen from £3.60 in its founding year to £8.20 – where it currently stands in 2020. The Living Wage was introduced in 2016 and it applies to workers aged 25 and over. This is also binding legislation meaning that employers must pay qualifying members of staff a minimum of £8.72 an hour. There is also the Real Living Wage – not a government scheme but rather a campaign run by the Living Wage Foundation, an “independent movement of business and people who campaign for the idea that a hard day’s work deserves a fair day’s pay.” They believe that the current levels of both the Minimum Wage and the Living Wage are not enough for staff to get by on and that, in the real world, staff need more money to pay for their monthly rent, food, and other expenses. Unlike the Minimum Wage and the Living Wage, the Real Living Wage is set at the same rate for the UK except for London where the recommended minimum hourly rate of pay is higher. In this article, we take a detailed look at the current Minimum Wage, Living Wage, and Real Living Wage here in the UK and which factors employers should consider when paying their staff.

What is the current UK Minimum Wage?

Depending on the age of a worker and on whether they are an apprentice, the National Minimum Wage and Living Wages levels as of April 2020 are as follows:
  • if a staff member is 25 and over, £8.72 per hour
  • if a staff member is 21-24, £8.20 per hour
  • if a staff member is 18-20, £6.45 per hour
  • if a staff member is 17 or younger, £4.55 per hour
  • if a staff member is an apprentice, £4.15 per hour
Employees are entitled to this rate of pay as a minimum by law. It doesn’t matter if an employer is a small or private company as the legislation applies to any organisation which has employees. If an employer draws up a contract of employment which states that a member of staff will receive below the minimum wage, this isn’t legally binding. The Government’s Minimum Wage would override the employment contract essentially nulling the relevant term in the agreement.

Who is entitled to receive the Minimum Wage?

Employees must be at least old enough to leave school to benefit from the Minimum Wage. Other individuals who also qualify for the Minimum Wage include:
  • full time workers
  • part time workers
  • casual staff
  • agency workers and temps
  • people who work from home
  • apprentices (entitled to the current apprentice rate – see below for more information)
  • trainees and workers still on probation
  • disabled members of staff
  • agricultural and farm workers
  • workers from overseas
  • offshore workers

Apprentice workers’ wages

If you employ apprentices, the National Minimum Wage is applied slightly different. This is because you have to consider other rules when setting a level of pay – for example, if the apprentice in question is under 19, they qualify to receive the minimum apprenticeship wage. If the apprentice is over 19, they are then entitled to the correct National Minimum Wage for their age group after they have successfully completed their first year of their apprenticeship.

Who does not qualify to receive the National Minimum Wage?

There are some people who do not qualify for either the National Minimum Wage or the National Living Wage. They are:
  • if you are self-employed or run your own business or company
  • company directors of a business
  • workers who are under the school leaving age (normally 16)
  • individuals who work on a government programme, for example the ‘Work Programme’ or on a pre-apprentice government scheme
  • if you are a member of the armed forces such as the Army or the Navy
  • voluntary workers or volunteers
  • if you are a higher or further education student completing work experience or a work placement for up to 1 year
  • family members of the employer who live in the employer’s home
  • if you are shadowing someone at a place of work
  • non-family members who live in their employer’s house, share work and leisure activities, and are not charged for meals or accommodation (for example, au pairs)
  • young people on EU schemes such as Erasmus+, Leonardo da Vinci, or Comenius
  • prisoners
  • share fishermen
  • individuals working on a Jobcentre Plus Work Trial for up to 6 weeks
  • if you are living and working within a religious community

Guidance for employers and paying the UK Minimum Wage:

Employers are legally obliged to pay staff correctly. You must by law pay your staff the minimum wage or more for which they qualify. However, there are some payments which you should not include when you’re calculating the minimum wage. These things are:
  • extra pay for unsocial hours during shift work
  • tips, service charges, and cover charges
  • items the worker has purchased for the job and for which they are not reimbursed such as uniform, safety equipment and tools
  • if the employer has paid for travel to work
Further considerations you should take into account, but which do not affect the payment of minimum wages:
  • income tax payments and National Insurance contributions
  • wage loans or advances for a staff member
  • the repayment of overpaid wages from a staff member
  • meals or food for the staff
  • accommodation for workers if provided by the employer above the offset rate (either £8.20 per day or £57.40 per week)
  • any penalty charges a worker incurs due to misconduct

What is the difference between National Minimum Wage and National Living Wage?

The main difference between the two scheme is the age of the employees which each covers. The Living Wage was introduced in 2016 by the Government with its target being to reach 66% of median earnings by 2024.

How does the Real Living Wage differ?

The Real Living Wage’s calculations suggest that being paid at the current levels set for the Minimum Wage and the standard Living Wage allows for staff in receipt of either to comfortably meet their monthly bills including for basic needs like food or rent. Businesses involved in the scheme volunteer to pay their staff the real Living Wage despite their being no legal obligation to do so. Currently, nearly 6,000 UK businesses choose to pay their staff the real Living Wage. Employers including ITV, Google, Everton FC, Chelsea FC, IKEA, and other FTSE 100 companies are members of the scheme and their participation has been verified and certified by the Living Wage Foundation. As a result, 180,000 employees now benefit from the scheme and many of these employers use the Real Living Wage logo on their website and it forms part of their wider programme for corporate social responsibility. The real Living Wage currently stands at £9.30 per hour for the UK with the London weighting rate coming in at £10.75 per hour.

What should you pay your staff?

We know that every business is different and that most employers want their staff to be happy with the wages they receive for the work they do. Deciding on the level of wages to pay is difficult because you, as the owner, have to make sure that the reward you receive for employing people is commensurate with the risk you’re taking in doing so. When deciding the levels of wages, you set, key considerations include:
  • How much value do they add to the business? We appreciate that this is much harder to gauge with non-revenue-generating staff but try to examine how much company service levels or operational efficiency would be affected by someone’s absence to try to calculate a monetary value.
  • What is the average wage of someone performing that role locally? It’s then a commercial decision for you about whether you wish to pay at that level, pay lower, or pay higher.
  • What is the average wage of someone performing that role at a competitor? Your competitor(s) and you are fighting for market share so what would you need to offer promising talent to work for you instead?
  • Could you pay lower but incentivise staff with bonuses for hitting profitability targets?
Please contact us at Black and White Accounting with any questions or queries you have on the UK Minimum and Living Wage scheme as well as for constructive advice and feedback on your current wage structure. We have been helping clients for over 20 years and we offer a free hour-long consultation to discuss the structuring or legislation around paying staff, for any new clients. Our advice is confidential as well as being up to date with current laws and information. Call our team today on freephone 0800 140 4644 or email us at hello@blackandwhiteaccounting.co.uk.

item.title: Right time to grow your business
item.dc:creator: Black And White Accounting
item.content:encoded:
6 signs it’s time to grow your business

I read an article in City AM recently that reminded me of many of the clients I’ve had the pleasure of working with over the last two decades here at Black and White Accounting. Only 1 in 25 companies set up in the UK reach a turnover of £1m. Only one in 250 reach a turnover of £10m. According to the article, it would take a £500,000 turnover business to reach the magical £1,000,000 turnover level at an annual growth rate of 3% per annum. In her engaging article, journalist Emma Haslett says that “many business owners find themselves trapped” in a cycle where growth is barely keeping pace with inflation. The great question here is why? Emma’s belief, a belief I share, is that there is a fear among entrepreneurs about growth and about the increased responsibility. For many business owners, it’s daunting enough walking into their premises with their mind on the the thought that I have to find the wages at the end of the month for these 10 people. Imagine the feeling of walking through larger premises with the knowledge that 100 people (and their families) are dependent on you making more right decisions than wrong ones. These fears are very real and very genuine. The important thing to remember however is that Premier League footballers, Grand Slam tennis players, and stadium rock stars didn’t get to where they got to without help. Why should you, be any different? You see a lot as an accountant. A proactive accountant – something I’ve always prided myself on being – is like the person who gives directions to the driver in a motor rally. The driver is in full control but, at critical moments, my job is to spot both opportunities to save time and hazards which could knock us right out of the race. And it’s in that spirit as the direction giver in the rally car that is your business, I wanted to share my thoughts about the six signs I see in any business which tell me it’s time for that company to grow.

Sign 1 - your turnover is predictable

You’ve probably been running your business now for at least 2 years. You’ve gone through the immense learning curve that all company owners go through when you realise that being in charge means a lot more than just being good at servicing customers – there’s a whole other side to being the boss. You’ve learned to manage your time a lot better and, sometimes with your heart in your mouth, you’ve taken a leap into the dark and you’ve employed other people to start to take the workload away from you. You’re still working for the business but now you also feel like you’re working on the business at the same time. The experiments you’ve carried out into generating more revenue and servicing customers better and faster has now started to turn into your company’s “system” – your modus operandi. You’ve got comfortable with it and so have your staff. They know what you expect of them and they know what to expect of you. Everything seems very stable now – including you. The extreme emotional and financial highs and lows of the first year are slowly becoming a memory and you feel like the shield which surrounds you has grown greatly in strength. You’re much better able to cope with unexpected events that ever before. All of this has combined to create a company capable of generating stable revenues every month. They may vary slightly or there may be a slight upward trend, but you and your staff are now not panicked wondering where the next sale is going to come from.

Sign 2 - your profit margins are creeping up

You’ve also noticed that, as revenues have stabilised, you’re now making more money on the work that you did than 12 months ago. Your profit margins are creeping higher – some of this increased profit may find its way into your bank account as dividends, some of it on low-level business improvements, and some of it on modest pay increases for your colleagues. The person who started the business because of a passion to provide a superior product or service to customers is still there but, inside, you feel like more of a businessperson whose job it is to quality control your staff to make sure that they’re still reaching your high standards.

Sign 3 - the same customers keep coming back and asking for more

You might have stepped away completely or partially from fulfilment, but you’ve done it in such a way that your clients haven’t noticed any drop in your standards. So much so that word of mouth is spreading. Of course, you run your own advertising and marketing campaigns and this is still (and always be) the most successful way to bring in new customers. But those customers, however you found them, continue to come back and they continue to recommend your products and services to others. You find that you’re getting requests from the customers to provide more products and services to them because they’d rather you do what it is they want because yours is a company they can trust. And, in their minds, there are too few of those types of businesses about these days.

Sign 4 - Sometimes, though, you struggle to cope with demand

You’re really good at predicting levels of demand for your products and services so you know to make sure that, when you need it, there is extra stock or capacity available. You’re noticing though that, when demand spikes, you run out of room either to stock the products you need to stock or find the extra labour needed to do the job. In fact, although you greatly enjoy running your business most of the time, these spikes are the only real thing that causes you stress now. The stress is caused not by a worry that you won’t be able to service your customers but that you won’t be able to service them as well as they expect.

Sign 5 - the post-VAT cash continues to climb

There are two ways to look at VAT and both are equally as valid:
  • you have to find a significant amount of money on a particular day every three months to pay HMRC and it’s a pain in the a*se
  • it’s like a three-month interest-free loan from the government.
When you first registered for and paid VAT, it felt like the former. Now it feels like the latter because turnover and profitability are so predictable that you know that there’s no chance that you’re not going to be able to pay it off in full and on time. You might even use a bit of the VAT to experiment on something new from time to time you feel that confident about payment. And every three months (except, sometimes, for those quarters where your corporation tax goes out), the amount of standing cash you have in your bank account continues to grow.

Sign 6 - You feel hungry for success – it gnaws away at you

You like the fact that you’re making a decent return from a growing set of loyal customers but, in the back of your mind, you’re worried that you’re becoming complacent. You know the financial ebbs and flows of your business and you know that everything could be put in jeopardy with a sustained period of depressed turnover. You like the fact that the cash in your account continues to get larger after you’ve settled the VAT. Perhaps you’ve opened a savings account but, no matter how hard you try, you can’t get excited at earning 0.05% interest on your deposit. For a little while now, you feel that you’ve got this pretty much right but is this all there is? Is there nothing more? You know that you’re comfortable and that your business is built on strong foundations, but you also feel that you can do even more. And that feeling starts to turn into something else – frustration and dissatisfaction. Frustration and dissatisfaction at something which gave you so much pleasure not so long ago.

If this is you, what do you do now?

First thing’s first, you’re probably ready to grow and to become one of the 25 who grows their business past the £1,000,000 turnover level. This is a risk you’re thinking of taking – a big risk. If you decide to do this, the shield that you’ve built up around you will weaken substantially and you’ll feel prone to the extreme highs and lows that characterised the early days of your entrepreneurial career. But is it worth it? YES! Why? At the moment, you are the business despite the fact that you might delegate many of your previous responsibilities to others. If you get expansion right, the business will turn into its own living and breathing entity independent of you. While you might pine occasionally for the early days when you were needed, nostalgia is overrated. You’ll have financial freedom like you’ve never had before. You’ll know that you’ve created something of value and worth – an army of people walking into the premises you tell them to walk into and who do the things your managers tell them to do all the time earning you money. Please believe me when I say that some of my happiest customers run £100,000 a year businesses. In fact, most of my customers are happy but none are as happy as those earning a great living from a company which doesn’t need them anymore.

You will need help – and here’s why

The person that you were and are now may not have the skills and experience needed to scale a business without making costly errors on the way. I mean absolutely no offence when I say that but running a company from one premises with 10 members of staff is a lot easier than running 10 offices with 10 staff each in them. I remember when we went from one office to two – I turned grey in six months because I was inexperienced at that time. Every step you take needs planning to the nth degree. In an ideal world, you will have experienced accountants forensically examining your financial situation prior to expansion to help you understand what you can afford to do and when. Expanding a business always costs a lot more and takes a lot longer than you budget for and it’s always safer to build a business with significant margins of error at every stage. Talk to us here at Black and White Accounting. Over the last 20 years or so, the team here, with 160 years’ combined experience between them, have helped dozens of clients through this stage – even bringing in outside experts to help when necessary. Meet with us for an hour. Tell us what personal and professional financial success looks like to you. Tell us about your plans. Let’s start a conversation and see where it goes from there. To get in touch with us, please call on freephone 0800 140 4644, or email us at hello@blackandwhiteaccounting.co.uk.

item.title: The benefits of employing apprentices
item.dc:creator: Black And White Accounting
item.content:encoded:
Taking on an apprentice

As if young people didn’t have it hard enough. Just over a decade ago, the career prospects of many of Britain’s youngest and brightest were dealt a severe blow by the Great Recession and its prolonged aftermath. Now, in 2020, a new generation has to deal with the COVID-19 crisis and this is truly unchartered territory. Many companies’ bank accounts will have been drained by the lockdown, but they still have to trade – they have to navigate their way out of this. This may turn out to be a blessing in disguise for the young people in our country as employers seek to train them at a much lower cost rather than recruiting experienced personnel instead. The most obvious route for companies choosing this approach will be the apprenticeship system. In this article, we’ll consider the positive arguments in favour of recruiting apprentices and training them up from scratch. We’ll examine:
  • the commercial and operational benefits of taking on apprentices
  • the costs of the apprenticeship scheme
  • how to sign up for the scheme
  • budgeting for welcoming apprentices

The commercial and operational benefits of taking on apprentices

Young people may now select from over 1,500 courses spread across 170 business sectors. The number of courses continues to grow as inventive and adaptable apprentice training and recruitment companies build their educational courses around the needs and demands of employers and the interests and skills of apprentices. Aside gaining an extra body at a temporarily discounted rate to do work in your company, what other benefits will they bring?

Teach and learn from your apprentice

Your apprentice must be given time to complete their coursework and their study when on the job – most apprentice recruitment agencies recommend setting aside at least one day of the week for this. There will be parts of your apprentice’s course which bear little or no relation to the operational or commercial needs of your business although most of it will. However, the knowledge gained by your apprentice on topics your business does not normally concern itself with may deliver wider benefits to your company – your apprentice may make you aware of commercial opportunities that you can exploit with your existing infrastructure and your apprentice’s knowledge which you were unaware of before.

The energy of youth and the return on investment

Particularly in the post COVID-19 world, all employees will want to prove their worth to their employers to better ensure the likelihood of them being retained for the future. At least your existing staff already have a foot in the door – a motivated, headstrong young member of staff who wants to work and who wants to earn knows that they have to work hard to earn and keep their place within your organisation. We’ve all worked for and run companies where a team or a department has been shaken up in a positive way with the arrival of a new member of staff or a new manager who has a different approach. Your apprentice will have the same effect once they have found their feet and they have found mentors they can rely on to look after them. An apprentice is a blank canvass – unsullied with the way things were done at their previous employers and unconcerned with anything other than fitting in, proving their worth, and earning their keep. Reports demonstrate that the presence of an apprentice adds the equivalent of £214 productivity per week to a business – 72% of employers reported better company-wide productivity following the establishment of an apprenticeship programme. According to recent statistics, apprentices are far more likely to stay with you longer than employees you recruited through other routes too.

Corporate social responsibility

Many employers use the fact that they run an apprenticeship programme as part of their corporate social responsibility programme. It’s a way of demonstrating that your company is giving back and a way of tying it to the fortunes of the local community. You’re offering career paths to young people in the area – this is particularly valuable if you are located in a post-industrial area which hasn’t managed to shake off the financial and psychological effects of deindustrialisation. Recent research also found that, when selecting suppliers, many businesses would be more likely to choose a partner with an active apprenticeship programme.

The costs of an apprenticeship scheme

The current apprenticeship minimum wage is £4.15 an hour. This is minimum wage for apprentices under the age of 19 or over the age of 19 during the first year of their apprenticeship. In the second year and later of their apprenticeship assuming that they are 19, they must receive the National Minimum Wage for their age group. This is currently:
  • £8.72 per hour if 25 or over
  • £8.20 per hour if 21 to 24
  • £6.45 per hour if 18 to 20
  • £4.55 per hour if 17 or younger
There are two important conditions you must adhere to when employing an apprentice:
  • they must work for at least 30 hours a week
  • they must receive the same in-work benefits as every other employee
There is a cost to the course taken by your apprenticeship to which you must pay 5% - the government funds the rest. The 5% levy is waved for employers with fewer than 50 staff if you hire an apprentice between the ages of 16 and 18 or an apprentice between the age of 19 and 24 with an Education, Health and Care plan provided by their local authority. All employers receive a £1,000 bonus for hiring an apprentice between the ages of 16 and 18 or an apprentice between the age of 19 and 24 with an Education, Health and Care plan provided by their local authority. The first half is paid in the third month and the second half in the twelfth month. For all apprentices under the age of 25, you do not have to pay National Insurance Employers’ Contributions on their salaries. If your company’s annual wage bill is £3,000,000 a year or more, you must by law set aside 0.5% of that to pay the Apprenticeship Levy. The money paid by a company for the Apprenticeship Levy can be used to fund its own apprentice program.

How to start an apprenticeship programme

Your apprenticeship program may be one person, or you may choose to recruit 10. Whatever you want, get in touch with a local apprenticeship recruiter first – start here. Discuss with your provider the level of qualification you want your apprentice to study for – you can choose from:
  • Intermediate – Level 2 (equivalent to the educational level of 5 passes at GCSE, Grades A-C
  • Advanced – Level 3 (equivalent to the educational level of 2 A-Level passes)
  • Higher – Levels 4, 5, 6, and 7 (equivalent to the educational level of foundation degree and above)
There is flexibility in the system – if you have a particularly ambitious apprentice, some providers offer Advanced Level courses as an optional module.

Budgeting for an apprentice

An apprentice’s wage is an additional fixed cost. They’re also not like other new employees in that they have to be supervised – for most, this is their first experience of the working world and there will be some dramas along the way. Can you afford it? Will an apprentice add value to your business? Before you give the Apprenticeship Service a call, get in touch with us and we can work out both the indirect and direct costs of hiring an apprentice and what value they may deliver back to your company in return. Call our team today on freephone 0800 140 4644 or email us at hello@blackandwhiteaccounting.co.uk.

item.title: Understanding tax codes
item.dc:creator: Black And White Accounting
item.content:encoded:
The tax code on our own pay slips as directors and on our employees’ pay slips are used by employers, accountants, payroll processing companies, and pension providers to work out the level of income tax and National Insurance deductions when paying salaries. According to our research, hundreds of thousands of people a year in the UK search the Internet for help in understanding what the tax codes on their wage slips mean – there is genuine confusion out there. Although HMRC do a reasonably good job in explaining the tax system as clearly as possible, they are hampered by the fact that the UK tax code is so dense and complicated in the first place. If quantum physics were easy, why would the late great Stephen Hawking need an entire book to explain it? That’s the position that HMRC’s outreach team finds themselves in too. In this article, we cover:
  • what an employee’s tax code should be
  • how PAYE codes are worked out
  • the tax code for basic rate payers
  • what the 0T tax code is
  • tax codes and the Marriage Allowance
  • tax codes for people earning over £100,000 a year
  • the emergency tax code
  • how your tax code changes if you owe money to HMRC
  • the tax code for people with more than one job
  • taxpayer codes in Scotland
  • help with payroll from Black and White Accounting

What should an employee’s tax code be?

Your employee can check the tax code they’re on by using the interactive tool on the HMRC website. The millions of people in the UK who complete a self-assessment form annually however cannot use this tool at time of writing.

How are PAYE codes worked out?

When working out which code to apply to an employee, HMRC considers:
  • the tax-free allowance a person is entitled to
  • any income earned on which tax has not been paid
  • any benefits in kind you have receive on which tax has not been paid
Income which you’ve not paid tax on is then removed from your personal allowance – what remains is a person’s actually tax-free allowance for the year. Your personal allowance is included within your tax code, albeit with the last digit missing. If, because of tax not paid on other earnings or benefits-in-kind, your personal allowance was reduced from £12,500 to £11,000, the number shown on your PAYE code would be 1100.

The tax code for basic rate payers

For basic rate taxpayers, the PAYE code is 1250L for employees. You should assume until told otherwise by HMRC that this is the code to use for all members of staff.

What is the 0T tax code?

If an employee has no personal allowance because it has all been used up, the tax code on their payslip will be “0T”. However, many employers and their accountants, when waiting for the standard information an employee provides when they begin working for you, assign a 0T code to a new staff member as a temporary measure.

Tax codes and the Marriage Allowance

Introduced in 2016, the Marriage Allowance allows an employee earning less than £12,500 (or whatever the personal allowance is that year) to transfer £1,250 of their personal allowance to their spouse or civil partner as long as they are a basic rate taxpayer (earning £12,501 to £50,000 per annum). You can encourage your staff to take advantage of the Marriage Allowance by applying for it online here. When a couple takes part in the scheme, “M” will show after the numbers in the tax code of higher earner and “N” for the lower earner.

Tax codes for people earning over £100,000 a year

Once a person begins earning £100,000 or more, the letter in their tax code is “T”. At this time, your employee loses £1 from their personal allowance for every £2 above £100,000 they earn. Once their income has passed £123,000, they are no longer in receipt of a personal allowance.

The mysterious emergency tax code – what is it?

If you don’t use the “0T” tax code when an employee has started with you, they may be assigned an emergency tax code. The same is true of people returning to salaried work after a period of being self-employed, of staff receiving company benefits, and of staff in receipt of the State Pension. Emergency tax codes are not meant to be permanent. As soon as you have the information you need from a new or affected staff member to apply the correct tax code, you can do so by clicking here. Emergency tax codes in 2020/2021 are 1250 W1, 1250 M1, and 1250 X.

How the tax code changes if you’re in arrears to HMRC

HMRC collects money owed to it from taxpayers through the PAYE system. If instructed, you must make these deductions from an employee’s salary. Annual repayments are subject to a maximum limit depending on annual earning and the current scale is…
Employee's PAYE earnings Maximum annual tax repayment
Up to £29,999.99 £3,000
£30,000-£39,999.99 £5,000
£40,000-£49,999.99 £7,000
£50,000-£59,999.99 £9,000
£60,000-£69,999.99 £11,000
£70,000-£79,999.99 £13,000
£80,000-£89,999.99 £15,000
Above £90,000 £17,000
The repayment of debt, called “coding out” by HMRC, in this case would mean that you would have to withhold up to £15,000 from a member of staff if they earned between £80,000-£89,999.99. You then transfer the repayment to HMRC on the 22nd of each month together with your standard transfer of income tax and both forms of NI. You are more likely to encounter this situation if a member of staff has started working for you after a period of self-employment.

More than one job? Tax codes

For employees with two or more jobs at different employers, standard tax codes are:
  • BR (basic rate taxpayer)
  • D0 (higher rate taxpayer)
  • BR (additional rate taxpayer)

Taxpayers in Scotland and Wales

For taxpayers paying the Scottish version of income tax, their tax code is prefixed with an “S”. Scottish income tax differs quite markedly from income tax in the rest of the UK -
Tax band name Scottish bands Applicable income tax rate Tax band name Rest of UK bands Applicable income tax rate
Personal allowance Up to £12,500 0% Personal allowance Up to £12,500 0%
Starter rate £12,501 to £14,585 19% Basic rate £12,501 to £50,000 20%
Basic rate £14,586 to £25,158 20%
Intermediate rate £25,159 to £43,430 21%
Higher rate £43,431 to £150,000 41% Higher rate £50,001 to £150,000 40%
Top rate Over £150,000 46% Additional rate Over £150,000 45%
There is also a Welsh version of income tax however the bands are the same as in England and Northern Ireland. Welsh taxpayers’ tax codes are prefixed with a “C”.

Payroll and more from Black and White Accounting

Payroll is one of the more complicated tax calculation and deduction obligations placed on employers. It’s one of the easiest to make repeated mistakes on and, if an employer does make repeated mistakes, the compound effect of those mistakes will result in a likely fine from HMRC on top of repayment of any accumulated shortfall. Call our team today on freephone 0800 140 4644 or email us at hello@blackandwhiteaccounting.co.uk to discuss your current payroll arrangements to see if we can provide any assistance.

item.title: What makes a good business plan?
item.dc:creator: Black And White Accounting
item.content:encoded:
A clear and well-thought-out business plan is a significant asset to any company although, regrettably, most business owners who take the time needed to write one forget about it soon afterwards. Given how much time, effort, and brain space running a company takes up though, it’s not surprising that it gets pushed to the back of the queue especially when work is coming in and you’re having to put out internal fires. A business plan contains the information you need on whether your company is performing to target or not – are you doing as well as you want to? After all, it’s you who wrote the business plan and it’s you who decided on the financial and operational milestones contained within it. Good business plans should reflect your business and the world it operates in – it should include information and insight on:
  • the industry you are operating in – are you doing better than your competitors?
  • your sales and marketing plans and how effective they are
  • your finances and goals for growth – are you achieving them?
  • personnel and staffing – do you have the right team around you?
  • operating procedures – are your internal operations as efficient and do they leave as little room for error as possible?
  • geographical considerations and property – too much or too little space? Are you in the right location?
  • chain of supply – what if a key supplier ceases trading? Do you have back-ups? And are the relationships you have with back-up suppliers as strong as they need to be?
A solid business plan is a specific and highly detailed document which clearly communicates the company goals and your operating strengths and weakness so that you, other senior managers, and investors know where the company is at now and where it wants to be. The presence of a plan provides comfort to employees and investors – more than anyone, your staff and outside investors need to feel like someone is in control and that they know what they’re doing. In this article, we cover the 5 main areas that any comprehensive business plan should cover. It isn’t complicated to compose a business plan, but it does require time and effort for it to truly deliver results. We recommend including these five sections at a minimum to create a valuable tool you can continue to refer to ensure that your business is reaching its true potential.

The Executive Summary

This is your “big picture”. This is an overview of your entire business as it is now and how it will develop and grow in the future – in precise detail. Generally speaking, it should be 1 to 2 pages long – but no more than that. Describing the path, you intend to take in a clear and concise way will ensure that you, other readers, and investors understand the direction of travel and that everyone has an idea of what is expected of them on that journey. Use your executive summary to outline the current and future operation and goals of every area of the business – for example, department structures, the management of cash flow, the allocation of resources and stocking levels, marketing plans, accounting conventions, research and development aims, recruitment policies, and so on. Be brief here as you will be going into much more detail about these areas in the relevant sections of your plan later on.

The execution

How are you going to do it? Once you have outlined your main goals, the next step is to delve deeper into how exactly you are going to achieve them. An effective business plan always includes a detailed sales and marketing plan – how much will it cost to find a new lead and to convert a new customer? Marketing is essential for any business and no business will survive without targeted and sustained exposure to their desired client base. If no-one knows your business exists, how will you make any sales? You need to decide whether you will need to use/keep sales reps, the role of the internet in your advertising, whether direct marketing is an appropriate route to market and how to structure it, which geographical regions you’re servicing, and much more. What about service levels? Are you adequately coping with demands servicing customers when needed before, during, and after the sale? Many businesses don’t want to compete on price – we understand that – so you need to decide on what the differentiator for your business is and push it hard. You need to meet and exceed customer expectations – what are your plans for doing so? Is your internal structure helping or hindering you? Are there too many steps in a process involving too many people? Remove wastage and you increase profitability and response times. Getting more out of the staff that you have now in terms of revenue and profitability means that you are going to have to remove roadblocks from within the business that are preventing them getting to where you want them to get to now. Have you spoken with your staff to find out where problems are occurring within the business and asked them what they need to hit the goals you want them to hit? Getting from where you are now to where you want to be requires a root-and-branch review of every aspect of your business. Knowing how to get there is half the task – the other half is to provide staff with what they need and to be able to measure their performance along the way, making slight alterations if you have to.

The Team

Who do you need to succeed? People make your business what it is. Particularly if you’re going to be seeking funding, investors need to know what talent you have within your company and how you are best going to use them. A driven team with clear strengths and individual goals is arguably the most valuable asset a business has. A directionless team with no targets to aim for is a liability. Knowing in detail the skills and talent that each member of staff has to offer is important as is knowing which areas of weakness need to be addresses. Do you need additional people to help you achieve your target? Or can you do it more cheaply and give pay rises along with additional responsibilities to your existing members of staff without affecting service levels? You’re going to need your team to achieve your goals. Give them the power, the flexibility, the training, and the rewards they need to help them deliver for you.

The Bottom Line

What are your current financials like? Are you profitable or lossmaking? Do you have a healthy cash flow and good gross profit margins? A sales forecast is essential as is your cash flow and your income statement – otherwise known as your profit and loss – as well as your balance sheet. The more detail you can include in your financial plan, the better. Make sure to include:
  • your fixed costs – make sure that every item of expenditure delivers value back to your company
  • current loans and debts – can you pay them down faster to reduce your fixed costs?
  • plant, machinery, and equipment – do they aid or hinder capacity or quality of production? Do you need new machinery to keep up or to increase the number of orders you can fulfil
Accountants normally recommend that you predict sales and profitability on a month by month basis for the first year of trading a plan covers then every quarter of the following 2 years, respectively. This is definitely true however you should update your business plan every 12 months and break down monthly sales and profitability for the year ahead.

Competition for your customers

Who are you up against and who are you selling to? Who is your target customer and who are they already buying from? Whichever industry you are in, you need to research the other companies in your sector who are targeting the same customers as you do. Let’s say you are in the motor trade. You will need to find out who else is selling similar cars in the same geographical location as you and at what prices. You need to find out who is buying these cars and why they’re choosing your competitors over you? Is it the range of cars? Is it the price point? Is it the offer of an extended warranty? Could it be their website and the fact that they advertise on bigger platforms for greater exposure? By researching the competition and finding out what it is about them which makes them appealing to the customer base you’re targeting, you are also able to compare your own strengths and weaknesses. It’s a good idea to spend considerable time mapping out the product, services, and marketing plans of your competition to see where you can improve but also to see where you already really stand out.

Help with your business plan

Here at Black and White Accounting we are an established accountancy and business planning firm with over 20 years’ experience. We make it our mission to understand what personal and professional financial success means to each client and we help you map out the journey to get from where you are now to where you want to be in as short a time as possible and with minimum friction along the way. With this in mind, we’d welcome the chance to meet you and to find out your aspirations for your business growth. item.title: What expenses can I claim and how?
item.dc:creator: Black And White Accounting
item.content:encoded:
When is a claimable allowance not a claimable allowance? When HMRC says so. One of the finest lines which many accountants have to be careful not to cross is making sure that every expense we claim back on behalf of a client either in a personal or a business context is allowable. And we’re sure you believe us when we say that it’s genuinely not always as straight forward as it sounds. We wanted to share with you in an article not only the main types of expenses which we can legitimately claim back on your behalf but also those when there is an element of judgement required. In this article, we consider:
  • the standard expenses you can claim back
  • is work clothing claimable?
  • are IT expenses claimable
  • the annual entertainment allowance
  • legal fees
  • costs incurred when working from home
  • the Annual Investment Allowance
  • using an accountant to make sure you pay no more tax than you need to

Standard expenses you can claim

The straightforward definition of “profitability” is the difference between what you’ve sold and all of the expenses you incurred in making those sales. Those costs may be stock, wage costs, rental or mortgage costs for your company’s premises, advertising, marketing, delivery, telecommunications, and so on. But what is a legitimate expense? By HMRC’s definition, it’s something which is purchased for use “wholly and exclusively” by a business. If something is purchased which could be and is used for both business and personal reasons, whether it is an allowable expense or not is not always easy to determine.

Is work clothing claimable?

HMRC’s definition of a uniform is "a set of clothing of a specialised nature that is recognisable as a uniform and is intended to identify its wearer as having a particular occupation” (HMRC EIM32475). Standard work uniform on a construction site like steel-toe-capped boots and fluorescent helmets would qualify because they are “wholly and exclusively” necessary for the context. Likewise, a uniform you purchase for a member of staff which would ever only be worn when the employee is performing his or her duty meets the “wholly and exclusively” criteria. General clothing you purchase for staff members must be included on the P11d form – the form used to report non-monetary expenses and benefits you’ve provided to your employees. With uniforms and protective clothing however, you don’t need to include them on a staff member’s P11d form because they are considered as exempt. Which items of clothing would be exempt? Exempt clothing includes any clothing which could be worn for personal reasons as well as for business reasons. HMRC cites the example of someone purchase a formal evening dress to receive an award – this would not qualify because that dress may be worn for social occasions as well as for award evenings.

Are IT expense claimable?

HMRC will generally allow any expenditure under £500 as claimable revenue expenditure. For hardware and software costing more than £500, we would normally class this as capital expenditure (which doesn’t reduce your level of taxation). Where confusion may arise is for the purchase of a piece of equipment like a laptop which may be used for both personal and professional reasons. Unless you can prove that it’s only ever going to be used for professional reasons (virtually impossible), we would recommend you:
  • pay National Insurance Employer’s Contributions on the value of the laptop if you run a limited company or
  • claim it as a benefit-in-kind if you’re a sole trader.
For sole traders, this means that you’ll have to pay equivalent income tax on the purchase. So, if you are a basic rate taxpayer and the laptop costs £1,000, keep aside £200 for income tax.

The annual entertainment allowance

For directors of a limited company, you’re entitled to £300 worth of treats every year. These treats must not be monetary payments and no treat must cost more than £50. These treats are not subject to income tax or NI payments. For members of staff, you have a £150 annual entertainment allowance per head (on which you can reclaim the VAT). The £150 may be spend on food, drink, travel, hotel stays, and so on. If you spend more than £150 per head, the entire amount spent becomes liable for tax and NI so please be careful. We’re certain that you know this anyway, but you can’t claim business lunches to celebrate the clinching of a significant new deal.

Legal fees

Legal fees are allowable if you spend them on doing something which directly benefits the company like involving solicitors in trade disputes, lease renewal negotiations, rent reviews, employment advice, and debt collection. These transactions would be classed as revenue expenditure. Legal fees however are not allowable if, even for the benefit of the company, you use solicitors to acquire a new lease, buy property, or merge with or acquire another company. These transactions would be classed as capital expenditure.

Annual Investment Allowance

We’ve touched a couple of times in this article about revenue expenditure and capital expenditure. Revenue expenditure can be used to reduce accounting profitability and therefore the level of tax you pay whereas capital expenditure may not. Certain types of capital expenditure are allowable however when your company purchases:
  • expenditure incurred in plant and machinery demolition
  • fixtures including but not limited to bathroom suites and fitted kitchens
  • goods, services, and labour linked to a building’s ‘integral features’
  • goods, services, and labour relating to building alterations required to install other plant and machinery within your premises
  • items that you retain exclusively for the use of your business
Until 31st December 2020, you can spend up to £1m on these items of expenditure and claim them back as if they were revenue expenditure under the Annual Investment Allowance scheme.

Pay no more in tax than you need to with Black & White Accounting

Black and White Accounting’s clients benefit from paying just the correct amount of tax on their personal or company earnings because we make sure that every allowable expense is included and claimed for. While individual claims may be small, over the course of a year they often accumulate into a not inconsiderable sum and it’s always better to have that money in your bank account than the Exchequer’s. We’re offering a one hour’s free consultation with new clients – we can come to yours or you can come to ours (or we can do a Zoom call if you’re reading this in the era of social distancing). Let us find out about what personal and professional financial success means to you – we’ll put together a suggested package of services for you at a fixed monthly cost which we believe will add the greatest value to your business. Call our team today on freephone 0800 140 4644 or email us at hello@blackandwhiteaccounting.co.uk.
