item.title: The Loan Charge Story
item.dc:creator: Black And White Accounting
item.content:encoded:
With fifty thousand people presented with huge and unexpected tax bills and an argument over the retrospective nature of the charge, the loan charge fiasco has been a situation with tragic consequences. What is it? Are you affected? And can Black and White Accounting help?

Tax avoidance or devastating misunderstanding?

From HMRC’s perspective, this situation has quite clearly been a tax avoidance scheme. For many of those caught up in it however, including a large number of contractors and low-paid agency workers, it is a confusing misunderstanding that came from nowhere. Tax avoidance schemes are typically associated with the very rich, so how is it that people struggling to feed their families have become part of this problem?

The story of loan-based tax avoidance

Laws on tax are typically very tight, but some unscrupulous accountants make their fortunes by closely examining the fine print of the law and finding the holes in the rules. Knowing that their actions are not necessarily within the jurisdiction of the law, but by following the wording means, that they can offer solutions that closer represent tax avoidance than the true representation of the correct procedures. Morality, however, is far from objective!

Being paid with a loan

The loan charge comes from a particular scheme where rather than having income declared as a payment from an employer or client, it was declared as a loan and thus untaxed. These ‘loans’ then had a repayment policy which effectively put them never needing to be repaid - a ‘perfect’ way to move money from a company to an individual without incurring income tax or national insurance. And technically legal. The scheme became widespread at the end of the 1990s and was used by many companies in the early 2000s. Of particular note were umbrella companies and agencies, who were able to offer their contractors and staff a very favourable tax situation through use of the system.

HMRC’s response

It took many years before HMRC did anything about this particular tax avoidance scheme. The first legislation put in place to try to combat the problem occurred in 2011, but it wasn’t until 2017 that it was fully in force. Those who had benefitted from the scheme were billed for unpaid tax with a deadline of April 2019 - an unforeseen bill that ran into thousands of pounds for even the lowest-earning victim. Although HMRC offered payment schemes that could run for years to those who came forward before the deadline, the financial impact on affected families was considerable. The legislation rolled back to 1999, putting some people in the position of finding themselves billed for two full decades of underpaid tax.

The controversy

Because HMRC were charging people stretching back almost twenty years before the law came into force, it was seen as a retrospective charge. Many argue that the idea that HMRC can change the rules on tax extending into the past and then charge for back-payment accordingly is outside of the law and simply not right. On the other side of the argument, HMRC maintain that it isn’t retrospective, but retroactive; meaning that the scheme was always one of avoidance and never properly within the law at the time. It becomes a more reaching argument due to the wide range of people affected. With employees, agency workers and contractors on low incomes all hit with debilitating levels of tax debt, the retroactive nature of the rules is seen as morally unfair. This is further reinforced due to tragic incidents - at least four known cases of suicide have been recorded as a direct consequence of people being unable to face the financial devastation of the April 2019 bill.

The Sir Amyas Morse Review

Campaigners put pressure on Prime Minister Boris Johnson early in 2019 to stop the loan charge. Consequently, a full review led by the former Chief Executive of the National Audit Office, Sir Amyas Morse, was undertaken. Those protesting the charge were hoping that it will lead to a full cancellation of the charge and release tens of thousands of people from unexpected debt. The review was completed and published by the government in January 2020 with some benefits for those affected. All but one of Sir Amyas Morse’s recommendations were taken on board by HMRC, helping ease some of the burden on those facing enormous tax bills.

Halving the ‘look back’ period

The review recommended that the loan charge should not apply to loans entered into before 9th December 2010. This effectively cut the 20-year retroactive change to a 10-year one. This will not constitute a change in circumstances for anyone who used the scheme post 2010 but will help a great many people who were victims of the situation in the years between 1999 and 2010. However, it should be noted that it does not mean that any tax due on earlier loans is completely written off, and it is important that you still seek professional financial advice if this change affects you.

Exemption of reasonably disclosed loans

This review recommendation stated that if the taxpayer disclosed to HMRC that they were using a loan scheme on their tax return, and no action was taken, that the loan should be considered outside the scope of the loan charge. This applies to loans taken out between 9th December 2010, and 5th April 2016. In essence, this means that if you gave enough information on your tax return that HMRC could identify and understand the nature of the loan arrangements, yet did nothing to follow that up (by opening an enquiry, for example), that such loans should no longer be covered by the loan charge. Again, if this affects you, it is important to clarify your situation with professional financial advice.

Refunds of settlements

This next recommendation dictated that HMRC should refund any settlements that were already given (through ‘voluntary restitution’) if the loan now falls outside of the loan charge due to the previous two recommendations. The government note that HMRC will not be able to process any refunds until changes to the loan charge legislation have been enacted by Parliament.’

Spreading the loan balance

In order to mitigate the impact of the tax payments, Sir Amyas Morse recommended that the outstanding loan balances be optionally split over three years. This could be very beneficial for those on lower incomes. Previously, the entire balance of the loan would be added to any income for the year, likely pushing anyone on the basic rate of tax into the higher rate and meaning that much of the loan tax was calculated at 40%. By splitting the balance over three years, it will often be that the adjusted taxable balance remains at the basic tax rate, ensuring only a 20% tax on the loan balance. In some cases, this could halve the tax due. Speak to Black and White Accounting for help in calculating your tax if you believe these changes could help you.

Avoiding hardship and bankruptcy

One key recommendation was that no one subjected to the loan charge should have to pay more than half of their disposable income per year, and that no one should have to sell their home or use their pension to pay the bill. HMRC have confirmed that they will ‘not seek bankruptcy proceedings for individuals who have engaged with HMRC, competed an affordability assessment, and are solely unable to pay the loan charge’. In short, this reduces many of the loan charge fears, reassuring those affected that their homes, pensions and basic living standards are safe. It is clear, however, that these reassurances are only in place for those willing to actively engage with HMRC, and that any type of avoidance is not recommended. An additional review recommendation regarding payment terms means that those earning under £50,000 per year will automatically be entitled to a minimum of a five-year payment plan (seven years if under £30,000 p.a.). This doesn’t mean other payment plans aren’t available for all individuals - HMRC are always willing to look at bespoke payment plans based on an income and expenditure assessment - but it guarantees such plans for those earning less than £50,000.

The loan charge deadline

The deadline for filing a tax return for those with loan charge related issues has also been extended to 30th September 2020 (a change from the previously set 31st January 2020). This provides some breathing room to bring your accounts in order and set up any needed payment plans between now and the end of September. HMRC have confirmed that they will waive any penalties for late filing and late payment, and that no late payment interest will be added, provided that the return is filed and payment made (or an arrangement put in place) by 30th September 2020.

If you are affected by the loan charge

It is important that if you have a current payment plan with HMRC that you continue to make payments as arranged until any new assessment has been completed and replacement arrangements made. At Black and White Accounting, we are available to help you with advice and are able to contact HMRC on your behalf to make things easier. Give us a call!

Avoiding avoidance

Making sure that you follow the correct tax laws and pay your tax and national insurance on time is a key part of both personal and corporate financial management. If you are self-employed, a contractor, an agency worker or the director of a company, then it’s important that you have a trusted accountant to work with you. At Black and White Accounting, we can look at your tax with a professional and experienced eye, saving you where it is proper and appropriate and never steering you into any morally grey area! For more information regarding our services, or just for a no-obligation chat, fill in our contact form or phone us today!

item.title: Making a Trading Company Dormant
item.dc:creator: Black And White Accounting
item.content:encoded:
Some limited companies start as dormant and will always remain so. Some limited companies will be actively trading but then potentially cease trading, at least for a period. Whilst some of these will eventually close, whereas others will trade again, during the dormant period, the company may seek to reduce their ongoing filing responsibilities. To become dormant, there are several things the limited company will need to do, which we focus on here.
What is a dormant comapny How to make your trading company dormant - Inform Direct   *****    
First, though, it’s worth thinking about whether dormant company status is the right thing for your company and in another article we’ve looked at the main reasons why a dormant company will be maintained. You’ll need to be dormant for a full accounting period to be eligible to file dormant accounts, so dormant status won’t be attractive to a company if you’re definitely going to start trading again in just a few months.

A better way to manage company secretarial work

Inform Direct is the perfect tool to help make company secretarial work a whole lot easier: > Manage details of officers, PSCs and shares > Automatic updates to statutory registers > Easy filing of forms with Companies House > Create documents from 400+ templates > Backed by dedicated, passionate support
Start now

Find out more | Log on

You should also be confident that the best option isn’t just to dissolve the company: if you’re sure you won’t trade again in the future, there’s usually little benefit in keeping the company in existence. While dormant company status can greatly reduce the effort and cost involved in maintaining the company, there will still be some time and expenditure required.

What do I need to do for my trading company to become dormant?

To make an existing trading company dormant, you should:
  • Pay any outstanding bills and cancel any business contracts. These might, for example, include leases of buildings or equipment, insurance, utilities, telephone and internet services previously used.
  • Reconcile the amounts you’re due to receive from your customers and ensure you’ve received all expected payments. You’ll need to terminate any agreements with customers to provide goods and services.
  • If applicable, pay any outstanding VAT due to HMRC and (usually) cancel the company’s VAT registration.
  • Pay any final wages due to employees and close the company’s payroll scheme.
  • It’s usually sensible to close down the company’s business bank account(s). A specific requirement to remain dormant is that the company must not receive any interest payments so any interest bearing account certainly needs to be closed.
The company can only be dormant going forward if no transactions pass through it, with very few exceptions as to which transactions are allowed. While tidying up all the above details might be time-consuming, it will provide something of a clean break. If, for example, you decide instead to continue paying for utilities or insurance, the company won’t be dormant in HMRC’s eyes and you’ll have to continue to file normal accounts.

How do I tell HMRC my company is now dormant?

To confirm with HMRC, you’ll need to write to your local Corporation Tax Office stating the date on which the company became or will become dormant. Their contact details will be on correspondence from HMRC. HMRC will then send to your registered office address a ‘Notice to deliver a Company Tax Return’. This covers the period of business immediately before the company became dormant. You’ll need to complete and file the return and make a payment of any tax the company owes. HMRC will usually confirm your dormant status in writing within about three weeks. From the date your company becomes dormant, HMRC will stop treating your company as active – this means that you won’t receive a lot of the correspondence from them you’ve had until now. In most cases, you also won’t need to contact HMRC until the company begins trading again (or you choose to dissolve it).

What about telling Companies House?

You do not have to inform Companies House that your company is dormant until it is time to submit your annual accounts. Remember that full accounts for the period up to the start of dormancy will need to be filed as usual. For the first full accounting period for which the company is dormant, however, you’ll instead need to submit simplified dormant company accounts to Companies House within nine months of the company’s accounting reference date. That can greatly reduce the administration of maintaining the company and is the reason many people make their companies dormant. On an ongoing basis, dormant companies must continue to meet a number of other Companies House filing obligations, including:
  • The annual confirmation statement, which is entirely different and separate from the accounts
  • When a new director or company secretary is appointed or terminated (or they change certain details like their name or service address), an appropriate form must be submitted.
  • Changes to the company’s registered office address or, if one exists, a SAIL address must be submitted on the appropriate form.

What if the dormant company then becomes active again?

Most dormant companies will become active again at some point in their lives. If your company become active (for example, by starting to trade), you must notify HMRC within three months. The easiest way is to use HMRC’s online registration service to inform them that the company is now active.

item.title: Crypto
item.dc:creator: Black And White Accounting
item.content:encoded:
Cryptoassets are a relatively new type of asset that have become more prevalent in recent years. New technology has led to cryptoassets being created in a wide range of forms and for various different uses. This paper sets out HMRC’s view - based on the law as it stands at the date of publication – about how individuals who have cryptoassets are taxed. It does not explicitly consider the tax treatment of cryptoassets held for the purposes of a business carried on by an individual. The cryptoassets sector is fast-moving and developing all the time. The terminology, types of coins, tokens and transactions can vary. The tax treatment of cryptoassets continues to develop due to the evolving nature of the underlying technology and the areas in which cryptoassets are used. As such, HMRC will look at the facts of each case and apply the relevant tax provisions according to what has actually taken place (rather than by reference to terminology). Our views may evolve further as the sector develops. Where HMRC considers that there is, or may have been, avoidance of tax, the analysis presented will not necessarily apply. Find out about tax treatment of businesses with cryptoassets.
What cryptoassets are
Cryptoassets (or ‘cryptocurrency’ as they are also known) are cryptographically secured digital representations of value or contractual rights that can be:
transferred
stored
traded electronically
While all cryptoassets use some form of Distributed Ledger Technology (DLT) not all applications of DLT involve cryptoassets. HMRC does not consider cryptoassets to be currency or money. This reflects the position previously set out by the Cryptoasset Taskforce report . They have identified 3 types of cryptoassets:
exchange tokens
utility tokens
security tokens
However the tax treatment of all types of tokens is dependent on the nature and use of the token and not the definition of the token. This paper considers the taxation of exchange tokens (like bitcoins) and does not specifically consider utility or security tokens. For utility and security tokens this guidance provides our starting principles but a different tax treatment may need to be adopted.
Exchange tokens
Exchange tokens are intended to be used as a method of payment and encompasses ‘cryptocurrencies’ like bitcoin. They utilise DLT and typically there is no person, group or asset underpinning these, instead the value exists based on its use as a means of exchange or investment. Unlike utility or security tokens, they do not provide any rights or access to goods or services.
Utility tokens
Utility tokens provide the holder with access to particular goods or services on a platform usually using DLT. A business or group of businesses will normally issue the tokens and commit to accepting the tokens as payment for the particular goods or services in question.
Security tokens
Security tokens may provide the holder with particular interests in a business, for example in the nature of debt due by the business or a share of profits in the business.
Which taxes apply
In the vast majority of cases, individuals hold cryptoassets as a personal investment, usually for capital appreciation in its value or to make particular purchases. They will be liable to pay Capital Gains Tax when they dispose of their cryptoassets. Individuals will be liable to pay Income Tax and National Insurance contributions on cryptoassets which they receive from:
their employer as a form of non-cash payment
mining, transaction confirmation or airdrops
As set out in more detail below, there may be cases where the individual is running a business which is carrying on a financial trade in cryptoassets and will therefore have taxable trading profits. This is likely to be unusual, but in such cases Income Tax would take priority over the Capital Gains Tax rules. HMRC does not consider the buying and selling of cryptoassets to be the same as gambling.
The location of exchange tokens
This section is primarily for non-domiciled individuals calculating their tax liability on the remittance basis and for related Inheritance Tax purposes. HMRC considers that throughout the time an individual is UK resident, the exchange tokens they hold as beneficial owner will be located in the UK. HMRC has considered other possibilities, but at this stage in the development of these tokens has found that a residence basis most accurately fits the majority of transactions. This means a person who holds exchanges tokens is liable to pay UK tax if they are a UK resident and carry out a transaction with their tokens which is subject to UK tax.
Determining the location of exchange tokens
When considering the location of an intangible asset, the courts will generally look at the nature of the asset to find a suitable comparison. For Capital Gains Tax, sections 275 and 275A of the Taxation of Chargeable Gains Act 1992 provide statutory rules for determining when particular types of assets will be in the UK, but these are unlikely to apply to exchange tokens in most cases. It is HMRC’s view that:
exchange tokens have an economic value as they can be ‘turned to account’ - for example, exchanging them for goods, services, fiat currency (that is money declared by a government to be legal tender) or other tokens
exchange tokens are a new type of intangible asset (different to other types of intangible assets, such as shares or debentures)
the only identifiable party to consider is the beneficial owner of the exchange token
For Inheritance Tax, common law is relevant to the extent that Double Taxation Agreements do not determine the location (section 158 of the Inheritance Tax Act 1984). Using the residency of the beneficial owner of the exchange tokens to determine the location gives a clear, logical, predictable and objective rule which can be easily applied. If an exchange token is co-owned between 2 or more beneficial owners then section 275C Taxation of Chargeable Gains Act 1992 applies (for Capital Gains Tax). Each beneficial owner’s interest in the asset will be where that beneficial owner is resident. If one or more of the co-owners are UK resident, this will not affect the location for those co-owners who are not UK residents.
Income Tax
Financial trading in cryptoassets
HMRC taxes cryptoassets based on what the person holding it does. If the holder is conducting a trade then Income Tax will be applied to their trading profits. Only in exceptional circumstances would HMRC expect individuals to buy and sell cryptoassets with such frequency, level of organisation and sophistication that the activity amounts to a financial trade in itself. If it is considered to be trading then Income Tax will take priority over Capital Gains Tax and will apply to profits (or losses) as it would be considered as a business. As with any activity, the question whether cryptoasset activities amount to trading depends on a number of factors and the individual circumstances. Whether an individual is engaged in a financial trade through the activity of buying and selling cryptoassets will ultimately be a question of fact. It’s often the case that individuals and companies entering into transactions consisting of buying and selling cryptoassets will describe them as ‘trades’. However, the use of the term ‘trade’ in this context is not sufficient to be regarded as a financial trade for tax purposes. A trade in cryptoassets would be similar in nature to a trade in shares, securities and other financial products. Therefore the approach to be taken in determining whether a trade is being conducted or not would also be similar, and guidance can be drawn from the existing case law on trading in shares and securities. More information on the existing approach and case law for share transactions and financial traders can be found in the HMRC business income manual (BIM56800).
Mining
Cryptoassets can be awarded to ‘miners’ for verifying additions to the blockchain digital ledger. Mining will typically involve using computers to solve difficult maths problems in order to generate new cryptoassets. Whether such activity amounts to a taxable trade (with the cryptoassets as trade receipts) depends on a range of factors such as:
degree of activity
organisation
risk
commerciality
If the mining activity does not amount to a trade, the pound sterling value (at the time of receipt) of any cryptoassets awarded for successful mining will be taxable as income (miscellaneous income) with any appropriate expenses reducing the amount chargeable. The other taxable income: HS325 Self Assessment helpsheet has more information about miscellaneous income. If the individual keeps the awarded assets, they may have to pay Capital Gains Tax when they later dispose of them.
Fees from mining
Fees or rewards received in return for mining (for transaction confirmation) are also chargeable to Income Tax, either as trading or miscellaneous income depending on the:
degree of activity
organisation
risk
commerciality
If the individual receives cryptoassets as payment for the services provided then any increase in value from the time of acquisition will either give rise to a chargeable gain on disposal for Capital Gains Tax purposes or, in the case of a trade, get taken into account in computing any trading profits
Airdrops
An airdrop is where someone receives an allocation of tokens or other cryptoassets, for example as part of a marketing or advertising campaign in which people are selected to receive them. Other examples of airdrops may involve tokens being provided automatically due to other tokens being held or where an individual has registered to become eligible to take part in the airdrop. The airdropped tokens, typically, has its own infrastructure (which may include a smart contract, blockchain or other form of DLT) that operates independently of the infrastructure for an existing cryptoasset. Income Tax will not always apply to airdropped cryptoassets received in a personal capacity. Income tax may not apply if they’re received:
without doing anything in return (for example, not related to any service or other conditions)
not as part of a trade or business involving cryptoassets or mining
Airdrops that are provided in return for, or in expectation of, a service are subject to Income Tax either as:
miscellaneous income
receipts of an existing trade
The disposal of a cryptoasset received through an airdrop may result in a chargeable gain for Capital Gains Tax, even if it’s not chargeable to Income Tax when it’s received. Where changes in value get brought into account as part of a computation of trade profits Income Tax will take priority over Capital Gains Tax.
Income Tax losses
An individual who is trading may be able to reduce their Income Tax liability by offsetting any losses from their trade against future profits or other income. HMRC’s Losses: HS227 Self Assessment helpsheet has more information (including restrictions that apply). If profits from activities are taxable as miscellaneous income, losses may be able to be carried forward to later years. More information on this can be found in helpsheet HS325: other taxable income.
Capital Gains Tax
HMRC would expect that buying and selling of cryptoassets by an individual will normally amount to investment activity (rather than a trade of dealing in cryptoassets). In such cases, if an individual invests in cryptoassets they will typically have to pay Capital Gains Tax on any gains they realise. Cryptoassets are digital and therefore intangible, but count as a ‘chargeable asset’ for Capital Gains Tax if they’re both:
capable of being owned
have a value that can be realised
What constitutes a ‘disposal’
Individuals need to calculate their gain or loss when they dispose of their cryptoassets to find out whether they need to pay Capital Gains Tax. A ‘disposal’ is a broad concept and includes:
selling cryptoassets for money
exchanging cryptoassets for a different type of cryptoasset
using cryptoassets to pay for goods or services
giving away cryptoassets to another person
If cryptoassets are given away to another person who is not a spouse or civil partner, the individual must work out the pound sterling value of what has been given away. For Capital Gains Tax purposes the individual is treated as having received that amount of pound sterling even if they did not actually receive anything. If Income Tax has been charged on the value of the tokens received, section 37 Taxation of Capital Gains Act 1992 will apply. Any consideration will be reduced by the amount already subject to Income Tax. If an individual donates cryptoassets to charity, they will not have to pay Capital Gains Tax on them. This does not apply:
if they make a ‘tainted donation’
where the individual disposes of the cryptoassets to the charity for more than the acquisition cost so that they realise a gain
Allowable costs
Certain costs can be allowed as a deduction when calculating if there’s a gain or loss, which include:
the consideration (in pound sterling) originally paid for the asset
transaction fees paid before the transaction is added to a blockchain
advertising for a purchaser or a vendor
professional costs to draw up a contract for the acquisition or disposal of the cryptoassets
costs of making a valuation or apportionment to be able to calculate gains or losses
The following do not constitute allowable costs for Capital Gains Tax purposes:
any costs deducted against profits for Income Tax
costs for mining activities (for example equipment and electricity)
Costs for mining activities do not count toward allowable costs because they’re not wholly and exclusively to acquire the cryptoassets, and so cannot satisfy the requirements of section 38(1)(a) Taxation of Capital Gains Act 1992 (but it is possible to deduct some of these costs against profits for Income Tax or on a disposal of the mining equipment itself). If the mining amounts to a trade for tax purposes the cryptoassets will initially form part of trading stock. If these cryptoassets are transferred out of trading stock, the business will be treated as if they bought them at the value used in trading accounts. Businesses should use this value as an allowable cost in calculations when they dispose of the cryptoassets. More information can be found in the HMRC Capital Gains manual (CG69220).
Pooling
Pooling under section 104 Taxation of Capital Gains Act 1992 allows for simpler Capital Gains Tax calculations. Pooling applies to shares and securities of companies and also “any other assets where they are of a nature to be dealt in without identifying the particular assets disposed of or acquired”. HMRC believes cryptoassets fall within this description, meaning they must be pooled. Instead of tracking the gain or loss for each transaction individually, each type of cryptoasset is kept in a ‘pool’. The consideration (in pound sterling) originally paid for the tokens goes into the pool to create the ‘pooled allowable cost’. For example, if a person owns bitcoin, ether and litecoin they would have 3 pools and each one would have it’s own ‘pooled allowable cost’ associated with it. This pooled allowable cost changes as more tokens of that particular type are acquired and disposed of. If some of the tokens from pool are sold, this is considered a ‘part-disposal’. A corresponding proportion of the pooled allowable costs would be deducted when calculating the gain or loss. Individuals must still keep a record of the amount spent on each type of cryptoasset, as well as the pooled allowable cost of each pool.
Example
Victoria bought 100 token A for £1,000. A year later Victoria bought a further 50 token A for £125,000. Victoria is treated as having a single pool of 150 of token A and total allowable costs of £126,000. A few years later Victoria sells 50 of her token A for £300,000. Victoria will be allowed to deduct a proportion of the pooled allowable costs when working out her gain: AmountConsideration £300,000Less allowable costs£126,000 x (50 / 150)£42,000Gain £258,000 Victoria will have a gain of £258,000 and she will need to pay Capital Gains Tax on this. After the sale, Victoria will be treated as having a single pool of 100 token A and total allowable costs of £84,000. If Victoria then sold all 100 of her remaining token A then she can deduct all £84,000 of allowable costs when working out her gain.
Acquiring within 30 days of selling
Special pooling rules apply if an individual acquires tokens of a cryptoasset:
on the same day that they dispose tokens of the same cryptoasset (even if the disposal took place before the acquisition)
within 30 days after they disposed of tokens of the same cryptoasset
If the special rules apply, the new cryptoassets and the costs of acquiring them stay separate from the main pool. The gain or loss should be calculated using the costs of the new tokens of the cryptoasset that are kept separate. If the number of tokens disposed of exceeds the number of new tokens acquired, then the calculation of any gain or loss may also include an appropriate proportion of the pooled allowable cost.
Example
Melanie holds 14,000 token B in a pool. She spent a total of £200,000 acquiring them, which is her pooled allowable cost. On 30 August 2018 Melanie sells 4,000 tokens B for £160,000. Then on 11 September 2018 Melanie buys 500 token B for £17,500. The 500 new tokens were bought within 30 days of the disposal, so they do not go into the pool. Instead, Melanie is treated as having sold:
the 500 tokens she has just bought
3,500 of the tokens already in the pool
Melanie will need to work out her gain on the 500 token B as follows: AmountConsideration£160,000 x (500 / 4,000)£20,000Less allowable costs £17,500Gain £2,500 Melanie will also need to work out her gain on the 3,500 token B sold from the pool as follows: AmountConsideration£160,000 x (3,500 / 4,000)£140,000Less allowable costs£200,000 x (3,500 / 14,000)£50,000Gain £90,000 Melanie still holds a pool of 10,500 token B. The pool has allowable costs of £150,000 remaining.
Blockchain forks
Some cryptoassets are not controlled by a central body or person, but operate by consensus amongst that cryptoasset’s community. When a significant minority of the community want to do something different they may create a ‘fork’ in the blockchain. There are two types of forks, a soft fork and a hard fork. A soft fork updates the protocol and is intended to be adopted by all. No new tokens, or blockchain, are expected to be created. A hard fork is different and can result in new tokens coming into existence. Before the fork occurs there is a single blockchain. Usually, at the point of the hard fork a second branch (and therefore a new cryptoasset) is created. The blockchain for the original and the new cryptoassets have a shared history up to the fork. If an individual held tokens of the cryptoasset on the original blockchain they will, usually, hold an equal numbers of tokens on both blockchains after the fork. The value of the new cryptoassets is derived from the original cryptoassets already held by the individual. This means that section 43 Taxation of Capital Gains Act 1992 will apply. After the fork the new cryptoassets need to go into their own pool. Any allowable costs for pooling of the original cryptoassets are split between the pool for the:
original cryptoassets
new cryptoassets
If an individual holds cryptoassets through an exchange, the exchange will make a choice whether to recognise the new cryptoassets created by the fork. New cryptoassets can only be disposed of if the exchange recognises the new cryptoassets. If the exchange does not recognise the new cryptoasset it does not change the position for the blockchain, which will show an individual as owning units of the new cryptoasset. HMRC will consider cases of difficulty as they arise. Costs must be split on a just and reasonable basis under section 52(4) Taxation of Capital Gains Act 1992. HMRC does not prescribe any particular apportionment method. HMRC has the power to enquire into an apportionment method that it believes is not just and reasonable.
Airdrops
An airdrop is when an individual receives an allocation of tokens or other cryptoassets. For example, tokens are given as part of a marketing or advertising campaign. The airdropped cryptoasset, typically, has its own infrastructure (which may include a smart contract, blockchain or other form of DLT) that operates independently of the infrastructure for an existing cryptoasset. The tokens of the airdropped cryptoasset will need to go into their own pool unless the recipient already holds tokens of that cryptoasset, in which case the airdropped tokens will go into the existing pool. The value of the airdropped cryptoasset does not derive from an existing cryptoasset held by the individual, so section 43 Taxation of Capital Gains Act 1992 does not apply.
Capital Gains Tax losses
If an individual disposes of cryptoassets for less than their allowable costs, they will have a loss. Certain ‘allowable losses’ can be used to reduce the overall gain, but the losses must be reported to HMRC first. There are special rules for losses when disposing of cryptoassets to a ‘connected person’.
Claiming for an asset that’s lost its value
As with other types of assets, individuals can crystallise losses for cryptoassets that they still own if they become worthless or of ‘negligible value’. A negligible value claim treats the cryptoassets as being disposed of and re-acquired at an amount stated in the claim. As cryptoassets are pooled, the negligible value claim needs to be made in respect of the whole pool, not the individual tokens. The claim will need to state the:
asset which is the subject of the claim
amount the asset should be treated as disposed of (which may be £0)
date that the asset should be treated as disposed of
The disposal produces a loss that needs to be reported to HMRC. Negligible value claims can be made to HMRC at the same time as reporting the loss. More information about negligible value claims can be found in the HMRC Capital Gains manual (CG13120P).
Losing public and private keys
If an individual misplaces their private key (for example throwing away the piece of paper it is printed on), they will not be able to access the cryptoasset. The private key still exists as part of the cryptography, albeit it is not known to the owner any more. Similarly the cryptoassets will still exist in the distributed ledger. This means that misplacing the key does not count as a disposal for Capital Gains Tax purposes. More information can be found in the HMRC Capital Gains manual (CG13155).
Cryptoassets received as earnings
Cryptoassets received as employment income count as ‘moneys worth’ and are subject to Income Tax and National Insurance contributions on the value of the asset.
Cryptoassets provided in the form of Readily Convertible Assets (RCAs)
Cryptoassets are RCAs if trading arrangements exist, or are likely to come into existence, in accordance with section 702 of the Income Tax (Earnings and Pensions) Act 2003. Exchange tokens like bitcoin can be exchanged on one or more token exchanges in order to obtain an amount of money. On that basis, it is our view that ‘trading arrangements’ exist, or are likely to come into existence at the point cryptoassets are received as employment income. If an employer has a UK tax presence they must deduct and account to HMRC for the Income Tax and Class 1 National Insurance contributions due through the operation of PAYE, based on the best estimate that can reasonably be made of the cryptoasset’s value. More information on readily convertible assets can be found in the HMRC employment income manual - (EIM11900). If an employer cannot deduct the full amount of Income Tax due from employment income they must still account to HMRC for the balance. This is called the ‘due amount’. The employee must reimburse their employer for the ‘due amount’ within 90 days after the end of the tax year. If they do not, then a further Income Tax charge and National Insurance contributions liability will arise on an amount equal to the ‘due amount’ under section 222 ITEPA 2003. More information about PAYE: special types of payment can be found in the HMRC employment income manual - (EIM11954).
Cryptoassets which are not RCAs
Cryptoassets received as earnings from employment, which do not meet the definition of RCAs in section 702 ITEPA 2003, are still subject to Income Tax and National Insurance contributions. Employers do not have to operate PAYE on payments of earnings that are not RCAs. The individual must declare and pay HMRC the Income Tax due on any amount of employment income received in the form of cryptoassets (using the employment pages of a Self Assessment return). More information on filing a Self Assessment tax return is available. The employer should treat the payment of cryptoassets, which are not RCAs, as payments in kind for National Insurance contributions purposes, and pay any Class 1A National Insurance contributions to HMRC.
Cryptoassets provided by a third party in connection with employment
Where cryptoassets are provided by a third party, in connection with employment, an Income Tax charge may arise under Part 7A ITEPA 2003. A Class 1 National Insurance contributions liability may also arise under Regulation 22B and paragraph 2A of Schedule 3 to the Social Security (contributions) Regulations 2001. Employers must account to HMRC for the Income Tax and National Insurance contributions due through the operation of PAYE, based on the best estimate that can reasonably be made of the cryptoassets’ value. More information on Part 7A ITEPA 2003 can be found in the HMRC employment income manual - (EIM45000).
Subsequent disposal of tokens
Any disposal of the cryptoasset received through employment may result in a chargeable gain for Capital Gains Tax.
Record keeping
Cryptoasset exchanges may only keep records of transactions for a short period, or the exchange may no longer be in existence when an individual completes a tax return. The onus is therefore on the individual to keep separate records for each cryptoasset transaction, and these must include:
the type of cryptoasset
date of the transaction
if they were bought or sold
number of units
value of the transaction in pound sterling
cumulative total of the investment units held
bank statements and wallet addresses, if needed for an enquiry or review
Self Assessment tax returns
Many cryptoassets (such as bitcoin) are traded on exchanges which do not use pound sterling, so the value of any gain or loss must be converted into pound sterling on the Self Assessment tax return. If the transaction does not have a pound sterling value (for example if bitcoin is exchanged for ripple) an appropriate exchange rate must be established in order to convert the transaction to pound sterling. Reasonable care should be taken to arrive at an appropriate valuation for the transaction using a consistent methodology. They should also keep records of the valuation methodology. The amount of tax due depends on the individual’s personal circumstances including their residence and domicile status.
Other considerations
Pensions
HMRC does not consider cryptoassets to be currency or money so they cannot be used to make a tax relievable contribution to a registered pension scheme. More information on contributions can be found in the HMRC pensions tax manual PTM044100.
Inheritance Tax
Cryptoassets will be property for the purposes of Inheritance Tax.

item.title: Exporting goods from GB to EU
item.dc:creator: Black And White Accounting
item.content:encoded:
The UK is now out of the EU VAT regime and Customs Union from 1 January 2021 following the Brexit transition period. The UK has introduced its new Border Operating Model for the control of imports and exports of goods between the EU and UK excluding Northern Ireland (‘GB’ or ‘Great Britain’). Exporters from the UK should follow the following steps from 1 January 2021...
  1. Who will export the goods from GB?
  2. Obtain a UK EORI number
  3. Check if you need an export licence
  4. Ensure you are eligible for export VAT exemption
  5. Decide how you will complete export declaration
  6. Information required for your exit declaration
  7. Moving the goods
  8. EU import customs declarations
  9. Completing Intrastat after Brexit
These are covered in more detail below.

1. Who will export the goods from GB?

Determine who will be the exporter of record and therefore responsible for the UK customs paperwork and export clearance, transport, insurance and other issues relating to the goods movement. This is contained with the in the International Commercial Terms (Incoterms) agreed in the sales contract. Typically, it is the GB supplier. They may also take responsibility of the customs clearance and import VAT for the goods into the EU. This Brexit-popular Incoterms basis is known as Delivered Duty Paid (DDP).

2. Obtain a UK EORI number

The exporter will need a UK Economic Operator Registration Identification number from HMRC. This is a unique identification number used on export (and import) paperwork to identify the exporter with customs authorities. UK businesses should already have has this issued from HMRC in preparation for Brexit in 2019; it may be obtained quickly if not. EU businesses acting as the UK exporter may apply to HMRC for one.

3. Check if you need an export licence

Certain controlled goods require an export licence or certificate. This includes: chemicals; goods; excise goods; livestock and foodstuffs.

4. Ensure you are eligible for export VAT exemption

Export sales are exempt from UK VAT. However, to be entitled to this relief, the exporter will need proof of the departure of the goods from GB. This could include sales invoice, customs declarations, bill of lading documents and transport documents.

5. Decide how you will complete export declaration

As an exporter you may complete customs export declarations and processes yourself, or appoint an intermediary: 5.1 Complete your own customs export process You can purchase commercial declarations software This will enable you to complete your declarations and file with the UK National Export System (NES). You will need to apply to HMRC to register for NES and for a ‘badge’ for HMRC's online customs systems: CDS and CHIEF   5.2 Use customs intermediary The following parties are usually approved by UK HMRC to represent exporters:
  • Freight forwarders
  • Customs agent or broker
  • Fast parcel operators
 

6. Information required for your exit declaration

Irrespective of who completes the export paperwork, you will need to compile the following information:
  • Commodity code for the product, which identifies the digits that identify a product, its materials and production method. The EU uses the six-digit global Harmonised System, or HS Code, and adds a further two digits 'CN heading'.
  • Departure point and destination
  • Consignee and consignor
  • Nature, amount and packaging of the goods
  • Transport method
  • Any certificates and licences
  • An exporter statement of origin to allow your importer to qualify for zero tariffs.

7. Moving the goods

You or your customs intermediary submits the completed customs export declaration to NES for a unique consignment number. This enables you to export the goods from GB and clear customs.

8. EU import customs declarations

At the same time, the EU import processes must be completed to ensure your freight forwarder and transport provier will accept the shipment. If supplying on DDP (see above) this will be you. This includes:
  • Applying for an EU EORI number. UK importers and exporters into the EU will need a customs intermediary and use their EORI number. This is because they are now non-resident within the EU Customs Union.
  • Securing any import licence.
  • Having the exporter's statement of origin to qualify for EU zero tariffs under the 'rules of origin' requirements.
  • Completing EU customs import declarations for the EU member state of import, and this is filed with the relevant country’s customs system
  • Applying for deferred VAT / Postponed VAT to ensure you do not have to pay import VAT.
  • If you are clearing the goods, consider an EU VAT registration with Fiscal Representation obligation.

9. Completing Intrastat after Brexit

The UK's HMRC is no longer expecting monthly Intrastat declarations for the export of goods from GB to EU from 2021. However, movements between NI and EU will require Intrastat and imports from EU to GB.

Black and White Accounting

This is a summary guide for individuals and businesses, who are exporting goods from GB to EU from 1 January 2021. We will continue to do what we can to   This is by no means complete or conclusive, as even at this late stage, some of the details have yet to be confirmed/clarified. However, at this most difficult of times, we are doing everything we can to help and support as many people as possible, for example by keeping them up to date with all the latest news you need to run your business. Why not sign up to our newsletter using the link below, or follow us across Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, Twitter and YouTube where we will keep you up to date with Brexit news.
A Brexit checklist can be found at https://www.gov.uk/transition. This provides links to a variety of web pages that can provide targeted information to the business. Whilst a lot of the key websites are still being up to date, they will be a useful resource for individuals and businesses going forward. If you would like to discuss any business issues and how they may impact you in 2021, contact Black and White Chartered Certified Accountants today, or call 0800 140 4644.

item.title: Your guide to tax free childcare in the United Kingdom
item.dc:creator: Black And White Accounting
item.content:encoded:
With the UK government's tax-free childcare scheme, you could claim up to £2,000 worth of costs per child per year specifically related to childcare. However, only one in six eligible families are taking advantage of the offer and take-up of the scheme among Britain's self-employed and company directors is even lower. There are plenty of online guides which offer great advice and support to families on how to claim tax free childcare. This is another such article but Black and White Accounting are going to take a slightly different approach with our guide - we're going to focus on families where one or more of the people making a living in a household is self-employed or a company director.

What is tax-free childcare?

Tax-free childcare is a government-run scheme whose purpose is to assist working parents with rapidly-increasing childcare costs. For every £8 you pay your childcare provider, the government will top it up by another £2. You can receive up to £2,000 per child per annum up until the age of 12 (or £4,000 per annum for every disabled child up until the age of 17). There is a cap on payments from the government of £500 per quarter (or £1,000 for children with disabilities). This tax-free childcare payment you may be entitled to receive represents 20% basic tax relief on the first £10,000 worth of childcare costs per child. If you or your partner are not working, you may still be eligible for tax-free childcare if you are in receipt of:
  • the Carer's Allowance or
  • the Employment and Support Allowance (ESA) (previously called the Severe Disablement Allowance or Incapacity Benefit).

Free childcare in the countries of the UK

Tax-free childcare is not the only scheme of its kind available to parents in Britain. In all four countries of the UK, you can claim for 10 or more hours of free pre-school education or free childcare every week.

Free childcare in England

  • Each child receives 570 free childcare hours per year (parents normally use the service in term time meaning that, over 38 weeks, their children receive 15 hours of care)
  • If you or your partner earn at least £140 a week but each of you earns less than £100,000 per annum, you may be able to claim for an additional 15 hours.

Free childcare in Scotland

  • Every child in Scotland is entitled to 16 hours' worth of free childcare per week
  • Councils in Scotland are given extra money by the Scottish government to fund further hours of free childcare. Entitlement varies between council regions - click here to see how many additional hours your child may receive.

Free childcare in Northern Ireland

  • There are no free childcare hours offered in Northern Ireland but pre-school education is funded through the Pre-School Education Programme which, for 38 weeks of the year (term time), provides parents either 12.5 or 22.5 hours' worth of tuition a week for their children.

Free childcare in Wales

  • In Wales, the amount of free childcare varies per week depending on your local authority but it will never be less than 10 hours - click here to see how much each council offers.
  • Some areas offer up to 30 hours a week, 10 hours of which is made up by early education.

Who is eligible for tax-free childcare?

Tax-free childcare is available for families meeting the following criteria:
  • you're a parent to a child who is under 12 years old (or who is under 17 years old with a disability)
  • you’re under 25 or an apprentice earning the equivalent of 16 hours' work paid at National Minimum Wage or Living Wage levels
  • you (and your partner if applicable) work and you (both) earn at least the National Minimum Wage or Living Wage for 16 hours a week
  • you are on paid ordinary or additional maternity, paternity or adoption leave or you are in receipt of Maternity Allowance for another child
  • you are on paid shared parental leave
  • you are on sick leave
  • you are on paid annual leave
  • you live and work in the UK (excluding Armed Forces personnel posted overseas and other Crown servants)
  • your child is under 12 years old is disabled and under 17 years old
You won't be able to use tax free childcare if you earn more than £100,000 per annum or, in the cases of claims made by homes with two parents present, your household income is greater than £100,000 per annum. If you are in receipt of tax credits, Universal Credit, a childcare bursary or grant, or childcare vouchers, you can't claim under the tax-free childcare scheme. If you do make an appliaction and your are successful, any child tax credit or working tax credit you receive will cease immediately. If you've been self-employed for less than twelve months, there is no minimum income requirement you need to match to apply for tax free childcare.

Coronavirus (COVID 19) and tax-free childcare

Eligibility to receive tax-free childcare and/or 30 hours' free childcare did not change during the pandemic however HMRC did introduce flexibility to their qualifying criteria on a temporary basis. However, this additional flexibility was withdrawn on 8th January 2021.

When do I receive the tax-free childcare money from the government?

The money you receive from the government is paid into a "tax-free childcare account." You pay the childcare providers you choose direct from your tax-free childcare account. Whenever you pay money into your online childcare account, the government will top it up the same day (normally within two hours). Other family members and friends can top up your childcare account if they wish.

Childcare providers

To qualify for tax-free childcare, the childcare providers you choose must be regulated the ChildCare Register, the Early Years Register, or OFSTED. More than 70,000 childcare providers have joined the scheme but please do check that that your chosen provider's application has been approved by the appropriate regulator before you purchase childcare services from them. The types of childcare service provider you can use the scheme for include au-pairs, nannies, playgroups, nurseries, childminders, after-school clubs, and breakfast clubs. Some holiday camps also accept vouchers as do art, football, and tennis clubs. Childcare provided by home care workers is also eligible as long as they work for a registered home care agency.

Tax-free childcare - most frequently asked questions

What's the best thing to do for households whose joint income is £40,000 a year or less?

If you work (or you both work if you're in a couple) and you're paying for childcare, you should consider claiming up to 85% of your childcare costs back through Universal Credit instead of using the tax-free childcare scheme. Universal Credit recipients can claim back up to £646.35 a month for one child or £1,108.40 monthly for two or more children. You may wish to take advice on this from us before making a decision or, if you'd prefer, the Childcare Service Helpline can provide you with advice.

Should you choose childcare vouchers or tax free childcare?

Tax-free childcare was brought in to replace childcare vouchers - this scheme is still ongoing however it has been closed to new applicants since October 2018. Childcare vouchers were offered by employers for children up to the age of 15 (16 if disabled). Unlike the tax-free childcare scheme, there is no minimum or maximum earning limit. Childcare vouchers are generally better for smaller families with lower childcare costs. If you run a business and your partner is on the payroll of another firm, it may be worth your partner checking to see if their employer still issues childcare vouchers. If they do, get in touch with us and give us details of their scheme and we'll be able to run costed examples for you.

What will happen to the current childcare vouchers scheme?

The likelihood is that the childcare vouchers scheme will end in around 2034 when disabled children born in 2018 reach the age of 16.

What about tax-free childcare for single parents?

You can apply for tax-free childcare as a single parent although only one childcare account can be set up per child. If the other parent wishes to contribute, then they will need to pay into their child's online childcare account.

What about tax-free children if I'm on sick, annual, maternity, paternity, shared parental, or adoption leave?

You can apply for tax free childcare under these circumstances but:
  • you can't claim for 30 hours' free childcare for a child you're currently on shared parental or adoption leave to look after and
  • you won't receive tax-free childcare for a child you're currently on shared parental or adoption leave to look after until 31 days after you've gone back to work.
Regarding older children, you can claim tax-free childcare if you're not currently on shared parental or adoption leave. You may also qualify for Contributory Employment And Support Allowance or Carer's Allowance whether your partner is working or not.

How often do you need to complete the eligibility criteria form?

You need to confirm your eligibility for tax-free childcare every three months by using your online child service account. If nothing has changed in the intervening three months, you simply need to tick the appropriate box. You should also be sent a reminder to your personal email address four weeks before you have to re-confirm your eligibility.

What happens if my claim does not meet the necessary eligibility criteria?

If you no long meet the eligibility criteria, you may be able to retain your 30 hours' free childcare for a short space of time depending on your childcare provider's policies.

Help with tax free childcare for the self-employed and for company directors

Being a parent is difficult - being a parent with responsibility for running a business is every harder. Many benefits schemes are created without the self-employed and company directors in mind - we only have to think back to the coronavirus crisis to see that. However, 30 hours' free childcare and tax-free childcare are available to both the self-employed and to company directors. You've paid into the system for years and you're entitled to receive these benefits so, if you're eligible, you should make full use of them. To speak with one of the Black and White team on how to claim tax free childcare, call us on 0800 140 464 or click here to email us for more information.

item.title: Understanding your tax code - what 1257L and the tax code letters you see actually mean
item.dc:creator: Black And White Accounting
item.content:encoded:
Tax codes are used by employers and pension providers to work out how much tax they should deduct from your job or pension before the money arrives in your bank account. Each source of income you benefit from, whether from a job or pension, will have its own tax code so it's important to make sure that you check them all. In this article, the team at Black and White Accounting explains everything you need to know about the tax codes for every job or pension you earn income from as well as how to contact HMRC if you think you're on the wrong code or if you think you've overpaid or underpaid your tax.

Who has a tax code?

All full- or part-time employee who receive their wages via the PAYE system must have tax code. People in receipt of private pensions also have a tax code. People who are self-employed, unemployed, or in receipt ONLY of a state pension do not have a tax code.

Where can I find my tax code?

If you don't know which code you're on for a particular job or pension, you can find it either on:
  • your payslip - the notification you receive from your employer every time you're paid your wages,
  • your P45 - the form an employer gives you when you stop working from them,
  • your P60 - your employer's annual summary of your salary and the amount deducted for tax,
  • pension advice slip - for employees paying in to a private pension,
  • PAYE coding notice (sometimes called a P2) - HMRC's explanation of how your tax code was generated (usually sent out in March), or
  • HMRC's gov.uk website - you can check your tax code with HMRC online if you have an account with them.

What is the tax free personal allowance?

Before we explain the tax code, it's worth exploring what the tax free personal allowance is. In the UK, you'll allowed to take home £12,570 in pay before you start paying income tax (your National Insurance tax free allowance is lower). With the basic rate of tax at 20%, the full personal allowance saves you £2,500 a year in income tax. Contained within your code is the level of your personal allowance. Divide the figure contained by 10 to find out what it is. This is why most employees will see the figure "1257" featured in their actual tax code. The amount of tax free income you can earn usually changes every April in accordance with the Chancellor's previous budget.

Explaining tax code letters

Tax code Meaning
0T either your Personal Allowance has been fully used or your new employer needs more details they need to issue you with a tax code
BR this job or pension is taxed at the basic rate (usually a second job or pension)
C this job or pension is taxed using the rates in Wales
C0T for Welsh taxpayers, either your Personal Allowance has been fully used or your new employer needs more details they need to issue you with a tax code
CBR this job or pension is taxed at the basic rate in Wales
CD0 this job or pension is taxed at the higher rate in Wales
CD1 this job or pension is taxed at the additional rate in Wales
D0 this job or pension is taxed at the higher rate (usually a second job or pension)
D1 this job or pension is taxed at the additional rate (usually a second job or pension)
L entitles you to standard tax-free Personal Allowance
M a taxpayer who has received some of their spouse or civil partner's Personal Allowance
M1 emergency tax code for employees paid monthly
N a taxpayer who has transferred some of their Personal Allowance to their spouse or civil partner
NT this job or pension is not taxed
S this job or pension is taxed using the rates in Scotland
S0T for Scottish taxpayers, either your Personal Allowance has been fully used or your new employer needs more details they need to issue you with a tax code
SBR this job or pension is taxed at the basic rate in Scotland
SD0 this job or pension is taxed at the intermediate rate in Scotland
SD1 this job or pension is taxed at the higher rate in Scotland
SD2 this job or pension is taxed at the top rate in Scotland
T to work out your personal allowance, you'll need to consult with your employer
W1 emergency tax code for employees paid weekly
Y entitles you to a higher personal allowance because you were born before 6 April 1938

The L tax code

The L tax code means that you're entitled to recieve the standard tax-free Personal Allowance.

The K tax code

The K tax code is used for people whose untaxed additional income exceeds their tax free personal allowance. You'll see the K code on your payslip if you're paying tax you owe to HM Revenue and Customs from previous years through your job or pension. People in receipt of taxable state benefits or people who receive employee benefits from work are also often on the K tax code. Let's say that, as part of your job, an employer provides you with a company car for business and personal use and they pay for the road tax and the petrol you use. HMRC calculates how much this benefit and any other company benefits you receive are worth to you and they then reduce that amount from your personal allowance. The format for this tax code is "K" followed by the adjusted personal allowance worked out by the tax man followed by "L".

The T tax code

If you have a T code, you'll need to consult with your employer to find out more to determine the level of your tax free allowance for the year.

The 0T tax code

If your tax code is 0T, then you have used up your Personal Allowance for this tax year or you've started work for a new employer and you haven't provided them with the details they need to give you a tax code.

The M & N tax codes

The M tax code and the N tax code relate to the Marriage Allowance. The Marriage Allowance allows the lower earner in a marriage or civil partnership to transfer 10% of their tax free allowance to their spouse or civil partner if the lower earner is paid (usually) £12,570 or less and the higher earner between £12,501 and £50,270 before they receive Marriage Allowance. The M tax code means that you’ve received a transfer of 10% of your partner’s Personal Allowance whereas the N tax codes means that you've transferred 10% of your Personal Allowance to your partner.

The BR, D0, and D1 tax codes for a second job or pension

The BR, D0, and D1 codes are used in most cases when you have more than one job or pension. The meaning of these tax codes is as follows:
  • BR code - your pay or pension is taxed at the basic rate
  • D0 code - your pay or pension is taxed at the higher rate
  • D1 code - your pay or pension is taxed at the additional rate

The NT tax code

If your tax code is NT, this means that you're not paying any tax on the income you're receiving.

The W1 and M1 tax codes

If you're on emergency tax code, then you'll see 1257L W1, 1257L M1 and 1257L X on your payslip. W1 represents weekly pay and M1 represents monthly pay. You'll be placed on an emergency tax code if you don't give your employer the information they need when they notify HMRC that you're working for them. It's actually HMRC who decides the tax code you're on. Emergency tax codes are usually issued if:
  • you didn't receive a P45 from your previous employer or
  • if you start your first job and this is your first source of income part way through the tax year.
When you're on an emergency code, no account is taken of any allowances or reliefs you receive. In addition, if you start a new job in the fourth month of the tax year, then you should normally receive two thirds of your tax free allowance in your monthly pay packet. With an M1 tax code, only one twelfth of your personal allowance is recognised meaning that you'll likely pay too much tax. When you do eventually hand your P45 or P46 to your employer, your tax code will change to the correct one and you'll be reimbursed for the tax you've overpaid. However, if you don't get it straight away, HMRC will send it to you as a refund.

The Y tax code

The tax free income allocated to a person with a Y code is higher because they were before 6 April 1938.

The S tax code

The S tax code relates to Scottish income tax. If you live and work in Scotland and you receive the full standard personal allowace, you'll see S1257L as the tax code on your payslip. If your tax code is S0T, then you have used up your Personal Allowance or you've started work for a new employer and you haven't provided them with the details they need to give you a tax code. If you’ve got more than one job or pension, you may have one of the following tax codes on the list below:
  • SBR - income from this employer or pension provider is taxed at the basic rate in Scotland
  • SD0 - income from this employer or pension provider is taxed at the intermediate rate in Scotland
  • SD1 - income from this employer or pension provider is taxed at the higher rate in Scotland
  • SD2 - income from this employer or pension provider is taxed at the top rate in Scotland

The C tax code

Although employees are taxed at the same rate in Wales as they are in England, people living and working in the country have a different tax code system. Tax codes in Wales begin with C and, if you receive the full standard personal allowace, you'll see C1257L as the tax code on your payslip. If your tax code is C0T, then you have used up your Personal Allowance or you've started work for a new employer and you haven't provided them with the details they need to give you a tax code. If you’ve got more than one job or pension, you may have one of the following tax codes on the list below:
  • CBR - your wages or pension is taxed at the basic rate in Wales
  • CD0 - your wages or pension is taxed at the higher rate in Wales
  • CD1 - your wages or pension is taxed at the additional rate in Wales

Tax codes in Northern Ireland

Northern Ireland shares the same tax codes as England.

Tax code FAQ

What happens if your tax code is wrong?

HM Revenue and Customs expect you to tell them if you think your tax code is wrong. That's because, in their minds, they rely on information provided by you and your current/former employee to assign you with the correct tax code. If your tax code looks wrong, it probably is. You'll need to contact HMRC as soon as possible - you can do so at their website.

What if I've overpaid tax?

If you've paid too much tax because your code is wrong, you need to tell HMRC straight away on 0300 200 3300. If you're overpaying in this tax year (April 6-April 5), HMRC will tell your employer and they'll amend your tax code. On these occasions, employers refund the overpaid tax via your wages. They'll also send you a P800 ("simple assessment") letter at the end of the tax year. You can claim up to four additional years of overpaid tax. If your claim is older than that and HMRC were to blame for the error, they will consider the case sympathetically.

What if I've underpaid tax?

We've seen that you can claim back overpaid tax from the previous four tax years. Likewise, if you've underpaid tax, HMRC can also go back four years as well (although they can go back up to 20 years if you were deliberately underpaying tax in their opinion). HMRC will often agreement repayment plans for larger amounts. You may challenge HMRC's attempt to claim underpaid tax by using an A19 form if you can demonstrate a "reasonable belief" that your tax affairs were being propertly handled, that HMRC was given the correct information, and that the underpayment is less than 12 months old. If your underpayment is less than £50, then HMRC will generally write it off.

What about tax codes for people who complete a Self Assessment?

If all of your income is taxed through Self Assessment, you won't recieve a tax code. For people who are both employed and self-employed, you will have a tax code and the code you're given will depend on your overall level of earnings as well as how much you're paid from each role.

Why is my tax code not 1257L?

If your tax code is not 1257L, it will be for one or more of the following reasons:
  • you have more than one job,
  • you've never had a job before and you'll be starting one soon,
  • you've not had a job for a number of years,
  • you've not been living in the UK,
  • you receive universal credit, child benefits, or tax credits,
  • you earn more than £100,000 during a tax year,
  • you are retiring or you have retired, and
  • you're in receipt of employee benefits like healthcare insurance or a company car.

Check whether each job or pension you earn income from is correct

If you've found this page as an employee looking for advice on tax codes and to find out whether you're paying the right amount of tax, then we hope you've found the information we've shared on this page useful. It really does pay you money to make sure that employers and pension providers have assigned you with the correct code. It's also worth checking that not only for this tax year but for previous tax years whether you may be due a refund. For that, please get in touch with HMRC. If you want help on running your payroll and ensuring that every staff member receives the tax free income they deserve, please get in touch with us for more information. To find out more, please call our tax saving team on 0800 140 464 or click here to email us.
