item.title: Tax on dividends
item.dc:creator: Black And White Accounting
item.content:encoded:
If you're new to being a shareholder and/or director of a limited company, you may be aware of the term "dividends" but you might not be exactly sure of what one is. For many years up until around 2015, dividends were like a reward to business owners from HMRC and the Government for taking the risk of self-employment. With a good accountant by your side, you could use remunerate yourself through a mixture of salary and dividend payments and you'd pay far less in tax than people who worked for other companies. That's only fair, right? Limited company owners aren't entitled to sick pay, holiday pay, parental leave, and so on. You don't have the certainty of stable regular income and, last by not least, you are part of an army of a few hundred thousand Brits whose appetite for risk and bravery has resulted in the employment of millions of your fellow countrymen and women. You deserve recognition and that was provided in the form of dividends and the dividend voucher. However, these important benefits have been pared back significantly in the last few years as the Government has been on a mission to raise more money from each individual taxpayer so that they can pay down the borrowing incurred during the Great Recession of the late naughties. It still pays to take advantage of paying yourself in dividends but dividends aren't nearly as tax efficient as they once were. So, we decided to write a piece to show you how you can maximise the benefit you receive from choosing dividend income over normal salary. In this article, the team at Black and White Accounting cover:
  • What a dividend is
  • The tax on dividends
  • The personal tax free allowance
  • Your dividend allowance
  • The salary/dividend sp
  • Two dividend tax case studies
  • The procedures you need to follow to issue dividends
  • Reporting dividends to HMRC and how to pay tax on them
  • Ways to avoid paying dividend tax
Want to speak with one of our teams about dividend income and on how to reduce your annual tax bill? Please call our dividends specialists on 0800 140 464 or click here to email us.

What is a dividend?

A dividend is a distribution of retained profits within a limited company to its shareholders. As a very general rule of thumb, the division of company shares between you and your fellow shareholders determines the amount that you might personally pay yourself in dividends - something called "dividend distribution". For example, if you owned 75% of the shares in your company and your business partner owned 25% of the shares, then the amount you receive in dividends should be three times higher than your business partner to reflect the actual shareholding. It's not quite as simple as that and there are perfectly legal routes around this rule however. If you get in touch with us, we'll explain how it works.

The UK dividend tax - how much tax do I pay on dividends?

We can't take a look at the UK dividend tax without looking at the bigger picture with regards to personal income, specifically in relation to the personal allowance and the dividend allowance.

Personal allowance

Each tax year, you are entitled a personal allowance. This is the amount of money you can earn without paying income tax and/or dividend tax. That rate is currently is £12,570.

Dividend allowances

Every tax year, you're entitled to a £2,000 dividend allowance. This means that you can receive £2,000 in dividend payments without having to pay dividend tax.

Dividend tax rates and income tax bands

So, in the 2021 tax year,
  • Your first £12,570 of salary/dividends are tax free - this is your personal allowance (check that tax code 1257L appears on your payslip)
  • Your first £2,000 of dividend payments are tax free.
Let's look at income tax rates for someone paid exclusively via PAYE in England:
  • You'll pay 20% income tax on your taxable income between £12,571 and £50,270 (basic rate)
  • You'll pay 40% income tax on your taxable income between £50,271 and £150,000 (higher rate)
  • You'll pay 45% income tax on your taxable income over £150,000 (additional rate)
Black and White note - the personal allowance begins to disappear gradually once you start to earn over £100,000 and it disappears entirely if your taxable income is £125,141 or more. Multiply the number contained in your tax code by 10 to discover your actual personal allowance for the tax year.
The situation with the tax on dividends is different. Let's see what the dividend tax rate is depending on how much you take out of your company:
  • You'll pay 7.5% tax on your dividends if your taxable income between £12,571 and £50,270 (basic rate)
  • You'll pay 32.5% tax on your dividends if your income between £50,271 and £150,000 (higher rate)
  • You'll pay 38.1% tax on your dividends if your income over £150,000 (additional rate)
As you can see, whatever your income tax band, you'll paya lot less in dividend tax than you would in income tax. So how is this applied to the real world?
Black and White note - be sure to check out our dividend tax calculator by clicking here.

Salary/dividend split

Let's look at an example of someone earning £62,570 a year - that's £50,000 more than the personal allowance. For the purposes of this example, we're assuming that our subject is not saving any money into a private pension. If paid by salary, part of their pay will be in the basic rate band and part in the higher rate band. They would pay £12,528 in income tax and £5,134 in National Insurance leaving take-home pay of £44,908. If you paid yourself £12,570 in salary and £50,000 in dividends, you would pay nothing in income tax, £6,742.50 in dividend tax, and £360.24 in National Insurance leaving take-home pay of £55,467.26.

Salary/dividend split case studies

Example 1 - £8,840

You could choose to pay yourself £8,840 a year in salary. You won't pay any National Insurance and your company won't pay any National Insurance Employers' contributions. £8,840 is also above the Lower Earnings Limit for National Insurance you need to pay in to qualify for state benefits. You could also declare a dividend payment of £5,730 on top of £8,840 and pay no income tax, dividend tax, or personal National Insurance. After this point, this is when you'll start to pay tax on your dividend income.

Example 2 - £12,570

If your limited company employs staff, it may better to pay yourself £12,570 if you're eligible for the Employment Allowance (EA). Under the EA, HMRC refunds the first £4,000 of your National Insurance Employers' Contributions. The £514.74 Employers’ NIC your salary attracts will be refunded and you'll save £708.70 in Corporation Tax. You'll be better off by £348 a year paying yourself £12,570 if you qualify for EA than if you paid yourself £8,840.

What are the procedures for issuing dividends?

As we've seen, on a personal level, paying yourself by dividends can be far more tax efficient. It is complicated though because there are often other factors related to what your company pays in tax which you'll need to consider - please get in touch with us for a costed personal example for your situation. To issue a dividend, you need to hold a minuted meeting of directors (even if you are the sole owner) which comes to a resolution to issue you with a dividend voucher. The voucher contains the date on which a dividend is paid, the company name, the name of the shareholders receiving a dividend, and the amount of the dividend. Please keep all paperwork related to dividends and remember to send them to your accountants.

When is dividend tax payable?

You declare your dividend income on your self assessment tax return. If you complete a self assessment tax return, you must declare your earnings in full as well as pay tax on dividends and all your other incomes stream by 31st January following the end of the tax year (6th April-5th April). If you have tax to pay, you can make payment direct from your bank account, via direct debit, or on your debit card. You cannot make payment via a personal credit card although you can make payment (for a fee) by corporate credit card or corporate debit card.

How do I avoid paying tax on dividends?

You can't avoid paying tax on your dividend income but there are ways you can structure the way that you pay yourself to reduce your dividend tax liability including:
  • Using up your ISA allowance (including on the first day of the new tax year)
  • Tranferring assets to your spouse to invest in a Bed & Spouse & ISA
  • Transferring assets to your spouse which generate dividends of up to £2,000
  • Using your pension allowance
Please consult with your accountants before taking any of the above measures.

Keeping as much money as possible with Black and White Accounting

Here at Black and White Accounting, our job is to allow you keep as much of the profit you make from your businesses as possible from the taxman. To find out more about our services, please call our dividends specialists on 0800 140 464 or click here to email us.

item.title: Tax On Uniform - what every taxpayer needs to know about how to claim a uniform tax refund
item.dc:creator: Black And White Accounting
item.content:encoded:
Do you have to wear a uniform for work? Do you have to wash it, repair it, or replace it out of your own pocket? If you do, you can claim a uniform tax rebate going back over the last five years meaning that HMRC might owe you hundreds of pounds. It doesn't matter whether you're an airline pilot, a nurse, or a police officer - you can make a claim. There are dozens of firms out there offering to help you claim on your work uniform for a fee. We're going to show you how to do it for free. In this article, Black and White Accounting covers:
  • Why you can't claim on personal protective clothing
  • Who is eligible for a uniform tax rebate
  • How much your uniform tax rebate could be worth
  • How do you make a claim to HMRC?
  • Frequently asked questions about claiming tax back on work clothing
To find out more about our services, please call our tax saving team on 0800 140 464 or click here to email us.

Can I claim for personal protective clothing?

If what you do requires you to wear personal protective equipment, you should receive that from your employer free of charge. If you have to buy it, they should pay you back the costs. If they don't, for whatever reason, you may be able to claim tax relief on it.

So who is eligible for a uniform tax rebate?

To be eligible for this tax allowance, four main criteria have to be met:

1. You paid income tax in the relevant tax year

This means that you can't claim a uniform tax rebate if if's for a tax year in which you paid no income tax

2. The uniform you have shows that you work in a particular job

For example, a police officer, a nurse, or a shop assistant within a retail store wearing branded a T shirt containing the company logo. HMRC's test for this is that other members of the public would recognise your profession and/or your employer if they saw you on the street. You can try to make a claim for non-branded and plain clothing but there's no guarantee that you'll receive a tax refund in these circumstances

3. You have to buy the uniform and clean, repair, and replace it yourself

If your employer washes your uniform for you or provides facilities for you to clean your uniform, you can't claim.

4. You're required to wear the uniform by your employer

If this is the case, you have no option but to buy your uniform and, therefore, your uniform tax rebate claim is likely to be valid.

How much is this tax relief worth to me?

You can claim flat rate expenses of up to £60 for uniform maintenance. If you're a basic rate taxpayer, you'll get 20% of this sum back (£12). For higher rate taxpayers, it's 40% (£24). As with nearly all HMRC flat rate schemes, you don't need to keep receipts for the individual amounts of money you want to claim back.

HMRC's table of industries and occupations

The amount you can claim back with the flat rate scheme differs according to your occupation. Just below, you can see HMRC's latest table for claiming tax relief by specific professions. For example:

  • Motor mechanics in a garage repair shop have an allowance of £120
  • Pilots, co-pilots, helicopter pilots and uniformed flight deck crew have an allowance of £1,022, and
  • In practices where everyone is required to wear the same colour or style, nurses, midwives, chiropodists, dental nurses, occupational, speech, physiotherapists and other therapists, healthcare assistants, phlebotomists and radiographers have a shoes and stockings or tights allowance of £125.

What if I want to claim more back than the flat rate back?

If you wish to claim more than the standard flat rate payments, you'll need to keep receipts to prove your additional expenses and fill in on HMRC's P87 form.

How do you claim for uniform tax rebates?

If you've never made a claim before for a tax allowance or what you're seeking tax relief on cost your more than £1,000, you'll need to fill out either an online or paper form and submit it to HMRC.

If this is your first time claiming

Fill in the P87 form online on which you'll be asked for:
  • The name and address of your employer
  • What you do, your job title, and the industry sector you work in,
  • Your National Insurance details and your PAYE reference
  • Whether or not you're claim for flat-rate expenses, and
  • Your preferred method of payment - cheque or bank transfer.
If you'd prefer to print off the form and send it in by post, you can do so. The address to send it to is Repayment Claim, Pay As You Earn, HM Revenue & Customs, BX9 1AS. The P87 form will also ask you for any work expenses you've incurred. If you're just claiming for the uniform tax rebate, ignore the other section.

What about if you've claimed before?

As we mentioned before, if you've made a successful claim already, HMRC should have adjusted your tax code to make sure that the fact you wear a uniform and you're responsible for its cleaning, repair, and replacement is reflected in the tax you actually pay. If they haven't and you wish to claim again for expenses totally less than £1,000, call 0300 200 3310 between 8am to 8pm Monday to Friday and between 8am to 4pm on Saturday. You may receive a P810 form from HMRC - this is its "Tax Review" form which it sends out to check that your tax code is correct. You may also use the P810 to claim your uniform tax rebate although if you're claiming for more than £1,000 of expenses or you changed jobs during the tax year, the taxman will ask you to fill in an additional form.

When do I get the money?

When you've registered your claim with HMRC, your tax code will change to reflect your expenses if your tax rebate claim is for the current year. Although the amount will be very small, you'll see a slight increase in your after-tax pay from now on. If you're claiming for previous years, HMRC will adjust your tax code or they'll issue you with a cheque or make a bank transfer for your tax refund.

Uniform tax rebates FAQ

Can Armed Forces personnel claim for relief?

The way uniform tax rebates are dealt with by the Armed Forces is different. The difference is that your claim is dealt with through your tax code. When you make a claim, the level of your tax-free personal allowance is raised to reflect the costs you've incurred.

Can self-employed people make a claim?

Things are also different for the self-employed. You need to claim for tax relief on your self assessment tax return. To do this, you should claim laundry and uniform expenses on your tax return - if in doubt, ask your accountant for advice.

What if I only wear the uniform for part of the year?

You can still make a claim because the tax relief for cleaning a uniform is flat rate. This applies even if you only wore the uniform for one or two days in a tax year.

Can I claim for laundry costs if my employer provide laundry facilities?

No. Even if you don't use their laundry facilities, you can't make a claim for laundry expenses.

Should I keep receipts?

For most flat rate uniform tax rebates, you won't need to keep any specific requests. As with virtually all flat rate schemes provided by the taxman, you don't really required detailed bookkeeping records to make a claim.

Advice for specific professions

As long as you're personally paying to replace, repair, or clean your work clothes, you're almost certainly entitled to claim back money from the taxman. But you may also be able to claim for the following depending on your profession:
  • gambling industry - Personal Function licence fees and Security Industry Authority licences
  • lorry drivers - food and accommodation bills, medical examinations, and digital tachograph smartcards
  • teachers - protective gear for science or metalworking lessons, union subscriptions, and subscription fees for professional bodies
  • healthcare - professional subscription fees and insurance costs
  • airline crew - sunglasses, flight cases, passports, BALPA subscriptions, visas, and vaccination costs
  • security - Security Industry Authority licences
  • police officers - Police Federation subscriptions
  • mechanics - purchase, repair, and replacement of your own tools, safety gear, and more

item.title: The Coronavirus Recovery Loan Scheme (RLS) - what is it and how do you apply for it?
item.dc:creator: Black And White Accounting
item.content:encoded:
Launched on the 6th April 2021, the Recovery Loan Scheme is a new debt finance package backed by the government to provide businesses with the money they need to recover and grow following the restrictions imposed as a result of the Coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic. The naming is symbolic but important - the intended purpose of the scheme is not to help businesses survive. Instead, the purpose is to help improve cash flow management and to stimulate economic growth through investment. The government sees increasing the velocity of money as the key to full and sustained recovery - in other words, they want people to spend more money faster. The belief is that, in a short space of time, this will create a "fly-wheel" effect which will give business and consumers the confidence they need to purchase more goods and services. This will lead to economic growth, rising wages, and falling unemployment. The Recovery Loan was launched shortly after the Government's announcement to extended to Annual Investment Allowance temporary cap of £1 million to 1 January 2022. This all sounds good in theory and, in this article, we'll take a deeper look at the Recovery Loan scheme and what it might mean for your business. To find out more, please call our accounting and business team on 0800 140 464 or click here to email us.

What is the new Recovery Loan Scheme?

The coronavirus pandemic inflicted significant financial and operational wounds on British businesses and, in some cases, entire sectors of the economy. The Recovery Loan is a government-guaranteed loan designed to helped businesses recover and grow affected by coronavirus.
Black and White note - the Recovery Loan Scheme is adminstered and managed by the British Business Bank plc. Financial backing is provided by the Secretary of State for Business, Energy & Industrial Strategy. The British Business Bank plc is a development bank wholly owned by HM Government. It is not regulated by the Financial Conduct Authority.

Should I be happy or concerned that the loan is "government guaranteed"?

The government will guarantee 80% of the value of the loan but the borrower - that is, your limited company - will be liable for the remainder. In other words, the bank or financial institution will pursue your limited company for the debt in case of default. If they can't collect the entire amount from you, the government will repay up to 80% of the outstanding balance. But it's more complicated than that as we'll explore later.

Which types of finance are available with the Recovery Loan Scheme?

The Recovery Loan offers the following two types of financing:
  • for term loans and overdrafts, you can apply for £25,001 to £10 million and
  • for invoice-backed factoring and asset-based finance, you can apply to borrow from £1,000 to £10 million.

Which types of businesses are eligible for the Recovery Loan Scheme?

To access the new scheme, your business must:
  • have been adversely impacted by the coronavirus pandemic,
  • must be viable or would be viable had the pandemic not occured, and
  • trade in the UK.
The Recovery Loan is not open to:
  • state-funded primary and secondary schools
  • banks, insurers, or reinsurers (with the exception of insurance brokers),
  • public sector organisations, and
  • companies in ‘collective insolvency proceedings’.
All applications will be subject to fraud checks, credit checks, and standard lending assessments.

How do you apply for a Recovery Loan?

You need to approach a participating bank or financial institution to apply through the Recovery Loan Scheme. At time of writing, the lenders involved in the scheme include:
  • Adam & Company,
  • Aldermore,
  • Arbuthnot Latham,
  • Bank of Scotland,
  • Barclays,
  • Clydesdale Bank
  • Coutts
  • Danske Bank
  • Ebury
  • HTB
  • HSBC UK
  • Lloyds Bank
  • NatWest
  • OakNorth Bank
  • Paragon
  • Santander
  • Scania Financial Service
  • Secure Trust Bank
  • Skipton Business Finance,
  • RBS,
  • Triodos Bank,
  • Ulster Bank, and
  • Yorkshire Bank.

How much can you apply to borrow?

You can apply to borrow up to £10m from lenders accredited by the British Business Bank. The minimum loan available is £25,001.

What information and documentation will I need to supply?

The type of information and documentation you're likely to be asked for includes but is not limited to:
  • an up-to-date business plan
  • previous year's accounts
  • management accounts (including forecasts)
  • your asset register
  • information on other overdrafts and loans used by the business, and
  • information on your personal credit card debt, overdraft, mortgage, or loans.

Will I or my company be credit-checked by applying for the scheme?

The Recovery Loan application form requires you to provide permission to the bank or financial institution handling your request to run credit checks and fraud checks. Unlike when you applied for a CBILS, CLBILS, or BBLS facility, your application will be subject to bank's normal lending criterias.

Will I and my other directors have to give personal guarantees?

On loans of £250,000 or more, you have to provide a personal guarantee. If your business goes bust and it borrowed more than £250,000, you and the other shareholders in the company will be pursued for payment of the outstanding balance. In some cases, banks and financial institutions may look to secure the loan against business assets (property, land, equipment, vehicles, and so on) which may reduce your personal liability should your company not be able to repay the loan. Personal guarantees do not apply on loans of £249,999 or less (with some institutions, that figure is £299,999).

When will we have to start making repayments?

Repayments start one month after you take out the facility.

How long will we have to repay the loan?

The maximum term for loans and asset finance is up to 6 years. There are no loan arrangement fees on facilities worth up to £2,999,999. Companies borrowing £299,999 or less will not be penalised for repaying their loan early. For invoice finance and overdrafts, you'll have a maximum of three years to repay the loan.

What fees and interest rates will be added to the Recovery Loan?

There are no upfront fees to pay to apply for the Recovery Loan Scheme and lenders' interest rates have been capped at 14.99% by the government.

What if my company already has a CBILS or Bounce Back Loan?

As long as you meet the eligibility critera, you can still apply for a recovery loan even if you have taken out a facility under the Coronavirus Business Interruption Loan Scheme or the Bounce Back Loan Scheme (CBILS, CLBILS or BBLS).

How long will applications for the Recovery Loan be accepted?

Applications will no longer be accepted after 31 December 2021 subject to review by HM Government.

Build your own coronavirus pandemic recovery plan

While this funding may provide useful for some companies, the key to recovery for businesses affected by coronavirus-related government measures lies with the owners of the business. You've got to take credit for the fact that you've steered your business through the biggest economic shock in over 300 years. Thankfully, all signs point to a very quick economic recovery and there's a feeling among economists that there is a wall of pent-up demand and cash which will be spent in the coming year or two. And your business is there to take advantage of it. Now is the time to think about your own coronavirus pandemic recovery plan. We recommend that you:
  • Replace any expensive debt you have with cheaper Recovery Loan debt - you can pay your debt down over a long time for less money
  • Think about what it is you want from your business personally and professionally in the coming 12-24 months - can you afford it and, if you need external funding, how much do you need?
  • Look for new opportunities within your current market - carry out some research into the impact the pandemic has had on your most significant competitors and look to capitalise on getting their clients to come over to you.
Over the past 20 years, we have provided business planning for clients across a wide spectrum of sectors helping them to identify their strengths, shore up their weaknesses, and take advantage of growth opportunities. We'd welcome the chance to work with you and your business.

Working with Black and White Accounting

Every company was affected in some way by COVID 19. It's required all of us to think about the way we run our businesses and the way we manage what cash we have available in our business bank accounts. If you've come out the other end of it, you'll soon be trading in a marketplace similar to the size it was before the pandemic hit but with fewer competitors. Before you take out a Recovery Loan, make sure that your business proposition is sound and it's ready for trading in a post-COVID 19 world. You've survived - now it's time to grow. To find out more about our business growth service, please call our accounting and business team on 0800 140 464 or click here to email us.

item.title: How To Find An Accountant To Do Your Tax Return
item.dc:creator: Black And White Accounting
item.content:encoded:
Self assessment tax returns! Do those words bring on a headache? As we approach the winter months and the end of the year our thoughts may be turning to more exciting things than tax returns (psst! there only 11 weekends until Christmas!). However, now is a very good time to start thinking about filing your 2018-2019 tax return (if you haven’t already); instead of spending your Christmas hols completing it.

Do You Need An Accountant To Complete Your Tax Return?

There is no mandatory requirement for the self-employed or small companies, to use an accountant. So for sole traders and small businesses with straightforward accounts, or a low income that necessitates making savings, completing your own tax return is entirely feasible. With the advent of cloud accounting systems such as Xero, the process is even easier with all your accounting information held in one place. But there are good reasons why an accountant can be an asset to your business, and why you should delegate the job of filing your tax return to an expert.

Benefits Of An Accountant

Perhaps the major benefit is that you can pass that headache over to someone else! This also means that you can invest your time in more profitable ways, doing what you do best for your business. If you are only required to complete the short version of the self assessment tax return, then your accounts may be simple enough for you to justify spending the time on this yourself. However, if it’s likely to take you some time, consider what you could be doing instead… The other key advantage over completing tax returns yourself is that an accountant should be able to spot ways you can save money. In fact, even after paying the accountant’s fee you could make significant savings, especially if you have missed expenses that could be claimed for in the past. Error is also a factor when you file your own tax return, and you can’t be expected to keep up-to-date with tax law and its implications, especially if your business is unrelated to finance and accounting. Naturally, a trusted accountant will know exactly where you stand in relation to tax rules and regulations, and will give you the peace of mind that your tax return has been completed correctly.

Finding An Accountant that suits you

If you decide that you would like to get an expert to do your tax return, then now is the time to find an accountant. Don’t leave it until the last minute! Although many accountants offer a one off service for self assessment tax returns, their priority will always be with their existing clients, and therefore may not be able to fit you in if you leave it until the New Year. There are budget options online but many of these amount to little more than data input services, by the time you’ve provided the information you may as well have filed it directly to HMRC. It’s worth shopping around to find a service that also offers advice on expenses, business use of a home, pension contributions etc. so that you can potentially reduce your taxes. Of course accountants do not just complete tax returns, they perform a multitude of other duties too, including:
  • Book keeping.
  • Setting up and running company payroll.
  • Registering the company with relevant tax departments –VAT,Corporation Tax, PAYE, etc.
  • Dealing with company and accounting related correspondence – Companies House, HMRC etc.
  • Tax planning advice.
  • Budgets, cash flows & business plan reports.
  • Dividend administration
  • Business mentoring.
  • Providing professional references.
You can find an ACCA certified accountant in your area by searching here. So if you are a growing business it may be time to talk to an accountant about your long term plans, not just your year-end tax return. For holistic guidance tailored to your growing business, engaging with a professional self-assessment accountant can provide insights beyond year-end tax returns. At Black and White Accounting we look after clients with varying accountancy needs; from self-employed sole traders or freelancers, to limited companies including micro businesses and SMEs. If you would like to speak to a consultant about your business and accounting requirements, call us on 0800 140 4644 or email.
